story:
Short Summary

On March 31, 2014, a member of Open Carry Texas was exercising his right to self defense while on a walk near his home in San Antonio. San Antonio Police Department officers from the West Substation responded to what they claim was an individual waving his rifle around and pointing it at people.  Nothing could be further from the truth. This story is suspect because officer did NOT respond with lights and siren (indicative of an emergency call) nor did they identify themselves as police officers (see video below).

After approaching and recognizing that Henry Vichique wasn't a threat and that the call was a hoax, officers still attempted to disarm a law-abiding citizen walking home from a friend's house. As officers were about to let Henry go about his business and continue his walk home, another officer arrived on scene and decided to elevate the tension by tazing our member. Henry was then arrested for having a loaded firearm within city limits, a local ordinance that directly violates state pre-emption laws pertaining to firearms as contained in Local Government Code 229.001(a)(1), which states: "a municipality may not adopt regulations relating to...the transfer, private ownership, keeping, transportation, licensing, or registration of firearms, air guns, ammunition, or firearm."

Mr. Vichique was charged under San Antonio Ordinance Section 21-16, Carrying loaded rifle or shotgun. The ordinance reads, "It shall be unlawful for any person, other than duly authorized peace officers, to carry a loaded rifle or shotgun on any public street within the city or in a motor vehicle while the same is being operated on any public street within the city."  Open Carry Texas maintains, and has maintained since this issue was first brought to our attention last year, that this ordinance is unenforceable and void due to the Texas pre-emption laws as stated above.

Open Carry Texas strongly objects to the abuses suffered at the hands of San Antonio Police Department officers against a law-abiding citizen exercising his right to keep and bear arms. Once again, the SAPD has shown that their force lacks in training, experience, common sense, and a basic understanding of Texas law and rights afforded to Texans by virtue of our state and federal constitutions. Ignorance of the law is no excuse, but that seems to be the rule of the day in SAPD. Our rights do not end when the sun goes down.

Please help us defend Mr. Vichique against these gross violations of his constitutional rights to keep and bear arms as well as personal self defense. Mr. Vichique is 19 years old and newly married trying to begin a life of independence and shouldn't have to worry about his future because of a few rogue police officers.

What We Need & What You Get

The money raised here will go towards actual costs associated with Mr. Vicheque's defense other than attorney's fees. San Antonio attorney Joe Hoelscher has graciously offered to donate his time pro bono to defending him, but we need to help with his out of pocket costs. Any money left over in this account no used will be placed in a trust for any future violation of 2nd Amendment rights. 100% of funds collected (other than fees charged by Indiegogo or Paypal) will directly into this fund for future use. No loans or grants will be taken against this account. Donors have the right to demand accountability of where the money is spent at any time after the campaign ends.

 

The Impact

It is a state state of affairs that in a state like Texas, we have to fight for our 2nd Amendment and Section 23 (Texas Bill of Rights) right to keep and bear arms. If we fail to hold law enforcement accountable because victims of these violations can't afford to defend themselves, we might as well give up our guns now. Your donations help us in the fight to ensure that Texas doesn't become California, or Connecticut, or Maryland or New York. Your support of Open Carry Texas is support for the Second Amendment. When you support us, you're supporting law-abiding gun owners in the Lone Star State.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to donate monetarily, please consider contacting your state representatives and senators and demanding accountability of these encroachments against our right to keep and bear arms. Please visit this link to find out who your state representatives are: http://www.fyi.legis.state.tx.us/Home.aspx

story:
I am Mac MacDevitt - I am an artist heading up the My Lai Memorial Exhibit team for the Chicago Chapter of Veterans For Peace.

Our Indiegogo campaign ended on 11/5, but with the help of more than 100 backers we have raised almost 60% of our campaign goal - enough to ensure that the exhibit will be begin touring in March 2017. Visit us at the My Lai Memorial Exhibit for a tour schedule and information on how to host the exhibit in your area.

I came of age during the Vietnam War and avoided being drafted and sent to Vietnam by becoming a teacher, but I have always been haunted by the terrible suffering endured by the Vietnamese people. I began to explore how collaborative art projects can deepen our understanding and empathy. The exhibit allows participants to tap into the artist in each one of us and join together to speak up for social justice.

Our campaign to create the My Lai Memorial Exhibit is an extension of the anti-war movement that challenged the military’s narrative about the war. With their fierce and persistent opposition, the Vietnamese people and anti-war activists joined together to help end the war. It is now widely acknowledged that the Vietnam war was unnecessary, unjust and immoral. Yet it is clear that we continue to make the same mistakes in our wars today. Wars that cause death, destruction, and floods of refugees, just like in Vietnam.

With your contribution, we can finish our traveling memorial exhibit to honor the Vietnamese who died in our American War. We expect that thousands of Americans will visit the exhibit over our two-year tour across the country. Through a unique and powerful artistic process developed by VFP members, participants engage in dialogue, make amends for the damage Americans caused the Vietnamese people and renew their commitment to work for peace and social justice in the world now.


What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $27,000 to complete the traveling exhibit and go on tour starting in February 2018. As a nonprofit organization your donation is tax deductible to the extent allowed by law.

VFP volunteers are donating their time and energy to develop and travel with the exhibit. Your contribution allows us the assistance and materials needed to complete the exhibit, including:
Materials and Fabrication:  $10,000
Design Services:  $5,000
Travel Trailer:  $4,000
Equipment:  $3,000
Technical Assistance:  $2,000
Initial Travel Expenses:  $2,000
Operating Expenses:  $1,000
Total: $27,000

 

The My Lai Memorial Exhibit - What we will build with your funding
Area One – Exhibit Panels
16 or more informational panels help you to humanize and understand the Vietnamese as a people and the impact of the American War on families, the land and their way of life.

Area Two – Interactive Touch-Screen Simulation
Place yourself in the “sandals” of a Vietnamese farming family in a village where military activity is intensifying. You become aware of the difficult choices and painful consequences faced by Vietnamese families.

Area Three- Interactive Sculptural Collage Building
At the heart of the exhibit, engage in a unique artistic process to create sculptural collages. Dialogue with a trained mentor and connect what went on in Vietnam with your life today. How do we use violence in our society and in the wars we engage in today?

Area Four – Take Action Kiosk
Provide support to organizations that are actively engaged in remediation efforts in Viet Nam. Learn about local organizations that promote peace and oppose war and violence as a means to resolve conflict.

Area Five – The Sharing Wall
Digitally share images of your personal collage art with other exhibit participants and through social media.

The Perks

$10 - Your contribution recognized on the project website
$25 - An assortment of ginger candies from Vietnam (a big hit at the 2017 VFP Convention!)
$40 - “My Lai Memorial Exhibit" T-Shirt
$50 - 2018 Americans Who Tell the Truth Calendar
$65 - Vietnam - Not Just A War T-Shirt
$85 - YES + Dove T-shirt
$100 - Letters to the Wall book sent to you or your local library
$200 - Hand printed YES + Dove Banner
$350 - Skype tour of the exhibit with developer Mac MacDevitt
$750 - Private poetry reading with VFP’s Poet Laureate, Doug Rawlings
$2500 - Develop a sculptural collage for your cause/organization/NFP of choice with exhibit artist, Mac MacDevitt

What if we don’t raise funds we need for the full exhibit? We will start our tour with the core of the exhibit and focus on the key areas that support the heart of the exhibit - the sculptural collages and opportunities for dialogue and sharing. As we travel and participants have a chance to experience the exhibit, we are confident that we will be able to raise the additional funds we need to build out the rest of the exhibit for the subsequent tours.

The Impact

I first started working with sculptural collages as a graduate student in the late 1960’s. When I first saw the photograph in LIFE magazine of women and children being lined up just before they were shot by American soldiers in Vietnam, I felt as if I had been punched in the stomach. I developed my first sculptural collage to deal with these feelings.

At a recent social justice fair, participants explained that their collage spoke of concerns with US foreign policy, the treatment of oppressed people and the need to learn and understand what is really going on behind mainstream narratives. The conversations were heart-felt and intimate. When I sit with others today who create their personal collage and discuss their artwork, I feel hopeful that together, even in this troubling time, we can work towards peace and justice.

The National VFP Convention was hosted in August of this year in Chicago. We set up just a sample of what we have planned for our traveling exhibit. We had a sculptural collage for VFP members to work with, the same one featured in the video. The dialogue with these veteran peace activists confirmed the power of our artistic process. Here are a few examples of their work.

Risks & Challenges

We know that the content of the exhibit may be difficult and painful for many participants.

Our exhibit panels on the Vietnam War and the My Lai Massacre examines the tragic impact of our political and military actions on the people of Vietnam; a people who in the midst of the American War were wounded or killed and had their villages, their homes, their livelihood and their social fabric torn apart.

The exhibit explores how our governmental and military policies and practices developed, nurtured, implemented and then covered-up a campaign that led to the killing of 2 million Vietnamese civilians during the course of this war; a campaign that allowed and encouraged the atrocity at My Lai, and other mass killings on the ground and from the air with bombs and artillery shells.

So why is it important to remember the destruction we caused to the Vietnamese people? Our VFP chapter is a member of the International Coalition of Sites of Conscience. Coalition members include holocaust museums and sites where atrocities took place. Our Memorial Exhibit reflects the “memory to action” process that guides coalition members,“not only to preserve memories of historical events, but also to understand the context in which these events occurred and apply the lessons we have learned to today’s struggles for human rights and social justice.”  

We need to continue to make amends for ongoing human and environmental damage we caused in Vietnam. Bomb craters need to be filled. Kids have their hands blown off from unexploded shells. And children born with deformities caused by our use of defoliants like Agent Orange still need care.

To deal with this challenge, we have designed an exhibit that is welcoming, open and non-judgmental. We invite participants to process this difficult content in their own way. And we are there to listen wholeheartedly as people process their personal thoughts and feelings.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if you can not contribute to our campaign. We ask that you share our campaign with friends, relatives, co-workers, and veterans in hopes that they can contribute. Share on your social media pages or send our campaign link via email. Come and share the exhibit experience with us when we are on the road in 2018/2019.
If you know of any peace organizations that we ought to connect with to support our campaign or host the exhibit, please email us at mylaimemorialvfp@gmail.com.

LIKE OUR FACEBOOK PAGE

 

Additional Information:

Veterans For Peace is an international organization made up of military veterans, military family members, and allies. We accept veteran members from all branches of service. We are dedicated to building a culture of peace, exposing the true costs of war, and healing the wounds of war. Our networks are made up of over 120 chapters across the United States and abroad. 

 

If there are funds remaining after the project's completion or termination, they will be used by the Chapter to serve the cause of world peace. 

Acknowledgments:

Video Producer - Sam Bowers - www.SamDonaldBowers.com
Music by Sam Neipp
Animation - Dan Schiffmacher - www.danschiff.com
Lead Designer - Ashley Borg - www.ashborg.com
Project Management - Maggie O'Keefe - www.mtminc.co

 

 

We are continuing to fundraise on our site, www.mylaimemorial.org. Please consider contributing there.
story_txt:
I am Mac MacDevitt - I am an artist heading up the My Lai Memorial Exhibit team for the Chicago Chapter of Veterans For Peace.
Our Indiegogo campaign ended on 11/5, but with the help of more than 100 backers we have raised almost 60% of our campaign goal - enough to ensure that the exhibit will be begin touring in March 2017. Visit us at the My Lai Memorial Exhibit for a tour schedule and information on how to host the exhibit in your area. 
I came of age during the Vietnam War and avoided being drafted and sent to Vietnam by becoming a teacher, but I have always been haunted by the terrible suffering endured by the Vietnamese people. I began to explore how collaborative art projects can deepen our understanding and empathy. The exhibit allows participants to tap into the artist in each one of us and join together to speak up for social justice.

Our campaign to create the My Lai Memorial Exhibit is an extension of the anti-war movement that challenged the military’s narrative about the war. With their fierce and persistent opposition, the Vietnamese people and anti-war activists joined together to help end the war. It is now widely acknowledged that the Vietnam war was unnecessary, unjust and immoral. Yet it is clear that we continue to make the same mistakes in our wars today. Wars that cause death, destruction, and floods of refugees, just like in Vietnam.
With your contribution, we can finish our traveling memorial exhibit to honor the Vietnamese who died in our American War. We expect that thousands of Americans will visit the exhibit over our two-year tour across the country. Through a unique and powerful artistic process developed by VFP members, participants engage in dialogue, make amends for the damage Americans caused the Vietnamese people and renew their commitment to work for peace and social justice in the world now.

What We Need & What You Get
Our goal is to raise $27,000 to complete the traveling exhibit and go on tour starting in February 2018. As a nonprofit organization your donation is tax deductible to the extent allowed by law.VFP volunteers are donating their time and energy to develop and travel with the exhibit. Your contribution allows us the assistance and materials needed to complete the exhibit, including:Materials and Fabrication:  $10,000Design Services:  $5,000Travel Trailer:  $4,000Equipment:  $3,000Technical Assistance:  $2,000Initial Travel Expenses:  $2,000Operating Expenses:  $1,000Total: $27,000

 
The My Lai Memorial Exhibit - What we will build with your fundingArea One – Exhibit Panels16 or more informational panels help you to humanize and understand the Vietnamese as a people and the impact of the American War on families, the land and their way of life.
Area Two – Interactive Touch-Screen SimulationPlace yourself in the “sandals” of a Vietnamese farming family in a village where military activity is intensifying. You become aware of the difficult choices and painful consequences faced by Vietnamese families.
Area Three- Interactive Sculptural Collage BuildingAt the heart of the exhibit, engage in a unique artistic process to create sculptural collages. Dialogue with a trained mentor and connect what went on in Vietnam with your life today. How do we use violence in our society and in the wars we engage in today?
Area Four – Take Action KioskProvide support to organizations that are actively engaged in remediation efforts in Viet Nam. Learn about local organizations that promote peace and oppose war and violence as a means to resolve conflict.
Area Five – The Sharing WallDigitally share images of your personal collage art with other exhibit participants and through social media.

The Perks
$10 - Your contribution recognized on the project website$25 - An assortment of ginger candies from Vietnam (a big hit at the 2017 VFP Convention!)$40 - “My Lai Memorial Exhibit" T-Shirt$50 - 2018 Americans Who Tell the Truth Calendar$65 - Vietnam - Not Just A War T-Shirt$85 - YES + Dove T-shirt$100 - Letters to the Wall book sent to you or your local library$200 - Hand printed YES + Dove Banner$350 - Skype tour of the exhibit with developer Mac MacDevitt$750 - Private poetry reading with VFP’s Poet Laureate, Doug Rawlings$2500 - Develop a sculptural collage for your cause/organization/NFP of choice with exhibit artist, Mac MacDevitt

We will start our tour with the core of the exhibit and focus on the key areas that support the heart of the exhibit - the sculptural collages and opportunities for dialogue and sharing. As we travel and participants have a chance to experience the exhibit, we are confident that we will be able to raise the additional funds we need to build out the rest of the exhibit for the subsequent tours.

The conversations were heart-felt and intimate. Here are a few examples of their work.

story:
We broke something.

On April 25, 2014 No Bears Allowed performed improv comedy in the Student Services Building. In the midst of laughter and Kanye, Mitsubishi Galant took the stage for the final time. The audience was captivated by the comedians' passionate entrance until suddenly, one man emitted an audible gasp. Time froze and we attempted to put together the pieces of this tragedy. Plaid Shirt. Dry wall. Gaping void. Ryan's foot...?
Mitsubishi Galant gathered themselves like true professionals and carried on with the scheduled entertainment. We have attempted to do the same, but have reached a barrier.

We fix something.

FSU has placed a hold on No Bear's Allowed room reservations until we repent for our sins and pay for the repair. They are quoting the job at $225*, which is absurdly expensive for a club that receives no University funding and is comprised of 16 broke college students. 
Help us fix the hole. You could be the helping hand that aids a Comedic Revolution in Tallahassee, Florida**. 


*Our goal states $500 because Ingiegogo has a $500 minimum. 
**We have no revolution planned, but you know, it could happen.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Claire. I am a former fost/adopt child, one of hundreds of thousands who share a story no one I have ever met knows about. The abuse within our 'justice' system is rampant, the negligence provided within these homes provides illness to the point of death and mental handicap. While not every home is the same, effective results can be seen in the vast majority of children afforded the 'blessing' of this salvation who end up on the streets, on welfare or in jail. Since the day my entire life has been looking forward to has occurred, the date of my 18th birthday which gave me status as a human being, I have been looking into why and how these injustices have been able to occur. They go on because in many ways, what happens to minors is not yet illegal.

Freedom under 18 demands freedom and equal rights for the only population of the US still underrepresented. The US Constitution was written at a time when children were considered property, and while amendments have been made for women, blacks, minorities, the disabled, and the elderly, no such amendment has yet been made regarding children. http://works.bepress.com/kevin_maillard/6/

Freedom under 18 also demands the ratification of the Convention of the Rights of the Child; to take our place amongst the rest of our upstanding international community as a beacon fostering progressive human rights welfare. The US is the only UN member aside from South Sudan and Somalia not to ratify the Convention of the Rights of the Child, which is the first legally binding international instrument to incorporate the full range of human rights; civil, cultural, economic, political and social. It also prohibits prosecuting and incarcerating children as adults because their minds are too immature to form "criminal intent."
http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=45894&Cr=children&Cr1=rights#.UuCxlhDn_IU

Freedom under 18 is built to spread awareness of the widespread abuse within many American households. More specifically it focuses on America's most vulnerable population; those children within the complicated, inefficient, and rampantly abusive foster system.

With your help, the formation of this alliance will solidify and become a powerhouse for tackling these social injustices through petitions, campaigning for bills, and social awareness!

What We Need & What You Get

To get this nonprofit going, we need $400 for the application of 501(c)3 status. It is the projected cost of the 1020 form user fee. The estimated cost of an advisor to aid with the required  paperwork is $250. We are hoping to get this rolling by mid-July.

If the goal is not met, the gap will be filled by myself to meet the needs of the nonprofit.

The Impact

I have researched, and there is simply not enough awareness about the status of our nation's children. You will be helping to form the only group that unites the problems facing child welfare in our nation today, and gives a name to what is going on behind closed doors.

Other Ways You Can Help

I of all people understand not being able to contribute monetarily when I wish I could. Whether you contribute today or not, you CAN make a difference by visiting our page on fb, liking and sharing our posts. That spreads the word! The change is in the knowledge.  Please please please share and like us!!!


Additionally, if you have any thoughts, comments, questions, or stories to share, please send them to https://www.facebook.com/fostadoptrights

story:
At the YWCA-Knoxville in 2016...

66% of residents reported a history of domestic abuse.

95% of residents who partake in case management and/or employment counseling found and maintained employment.

63% of residents reduced debt for six months or more.

57% of residents have saved money for six months or more. 

 

Check Out Our Blog!

https://joingingthemissionwithywca.wordpress.com

 

About "Joining the Mission with YWCA."

We are Hancen Sale, Malena Torres, Alexandra Eleas, and Madison Thomas, a group of students at the University of Tennessee-Knoxville, interested in bettering our local community. This being said, through a Public Writing class, we were presented with the amazing opportunity to raise money for the deserving non-profit, YWCA-Knoxville’s Women's Transitional Housing Program. 

What We Need.

As fierce advocates for both eliminating racism and empowering women, we have set our goal on raising $1,000 for this unique non-profit. It is our sincere intentions, through learning the ropes of public advocacy and better understanding the needs of our local community, to bring about real and tangible change in the lives of local women. With your special donations, our team can help support YWCA residents through assisting the following capacities:

  • Affordable Housing
  • Bi-monthly goal assessments 
  • Financial Literacy classes
  • Monthly Wellness classes
  • Computer class
  • Support groups
  • Counseling 

The Impact.

With your help, we have the power to change the lives of women and children both in and around the Knoxville community. Donations will help provide the cost of program fees and other useful items to enhance the lives of women in the program. As citizens of Knoxville, we have a duty to our women. A duty to empower, affirm and inspire women to be the best they can possibly be.  We need you to join the mission and help us be the change!

Risk & Challenges.

Raising $1,000 isn't easy, which is why we need YOU! We are challenging you to join the mission and give to the YWCA is whatever way you can. Whether it be through donations, sharing this page, or simply through word of mouth; we urge you to join us in advocating for this organization.

Other Ways You Can Help.

Aren't able to donate time or money, but still want to make a difference? Spread the word! We are trying to reach as many people as possible during this campaign, and you can make a difference in that number. Please help us by sharing our cause to any social media outlet you are a part of(such as Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter). Join the Mission with YWCA, and help us inform the community about our fight to eliminate racism and empower women. 

Visit YWCA's Website.

https://www.ywcaknox.com

Support resistance art. Amplify our voices. 

Tell lawmakers, corporations, and media what you think. Create a protest slogan or demonstrate your support for progressive programs. Add a stamp, and drop it in the mail.

Be heard. Be seen. Be Strong. Be Fearless.

Take Action!

story:
Fatal Encounters documents the people who have been killed by police in the United States since 2000.

Until us, nobody could say how many people are killed by police in this country.  No government authority. No lobbying group. No watchdog organization. Nobody.  Nobody could reliably describe the size or shape of fatal police violence in the U.S.  

That’s a problem.  We’re solving that problem.  That’s our mission.  

Since 2012, Fatal Encounters has been building an impartial, comprehensive, searchable national database of people killed during interactions with law enforcement at FatalEncounters.org.  Our main database is open source.  Everyone is welcome to search for names online, analyze the results, or download the entire spreadsheet for free at any time.  

 

 

Our effort has already been effective.  In 2014, during the crisis in Ferguson, Missouri, Fatal Encounters' key contribution was to show that the annual total of police killings was more than three times larger than the official numbers.  For years, the FBI has reported that between 300 and 400 people are killed by police each year. They call each death a "justifiable" homicide in their reports. Based on 2013 and 2014 data, we've proven beyond dispute that the number of people who die is closer to 1,700. 

We’re proud to move the national conversation forward.  

 

 

Other, bigger media outlets—like the Washington Post—have joined the chorus.  Their voices are welcome, but the scope, depth, discipline, potential, and open-source philosophy of Fatal Encounters remains unique.  In a May 1, 2015, front-page story the New York Times described Fatal Encounters as “the most meticulous” of all similar projects.  

 

 

We've also empowered universities and smaller organizations—even individuals—to advocate for change using our data. Samuel Sinyangwe and DeRay Mckesson use our data in their Mapping Police Violence project in support of #BlackLivesMatter. 

Even members of law enforcement uses our data. For example, in his book, In Context: Understanding Police Killings of Unarmed Civilians, Texas Police Detective Nick Selby drew extensively from our data. In a Department of Justice study published in December, FatalEncounters' data most closely exemplified the DoJ's best-practices hopes for a program that looked great--but apparently was not funded.

Some killings, like those of Michael Brown, Philando Castile, and Justine Damond, draw exhaustive coverage, and Fatal Encounters has been a part of the discussion: AlJazeera, CTGN America ... and even The Daily Show with Jon Stewart.  But the sad fact is, most killings escape public attention, retrievable only from two or three paragraphs in local newspapers.  Anybody who’s serious about drawing conclusions must first see the whole pattern.  As Senator Cory Booker pointed out when he sponsored legislation to improve tracking of police brutality: “The first step in fixing a problem is understanding the extent of the problem you have.”  When you hear it like that, it sounds obvious.  

The first draft of our database is about 94 percent complete. We've documented more than 21,800 deaths during police interactions.  At our current rate, we hope to have the draft complete in October 2017.  Our intention for the next phase of Fatal Encounters is to make the data even more useful by including data on whether the person was armed, mentally ill or a veteran. It's also our intention to add data regarding officers killed in the line of duty, so the dataset can be truly comprehensive.

Please help us push this conversation forward. Tell your friends. Share it on social media. Tell your co-workers.  We’re a 501(c)3 so donations can be tax-deductible. While we are a nonprofit, this fundraising campaign is not using  Indiegogo's nonprofit platform for logistical reasons. Particularly for larger donations, if you would like your donation to be tax-deductible, donate directly to Fatal Encounters Dot Org. You'll get all the perks that we've described here, it just won't change the total on this page. You can make a difference. 

 

 

Where Will the Money Go?

In this campaign, we're trying to raise the money we need to run Fatal Encounters Dot Org for six months. The biggest portion is salary for the executive director, who is also our primary researcher and fact-checker. The rest of the funds will go to operational expenses like per-record researchers, web hosting, and government taxes and fees.  
 

FAQ

 

1)  What is Fatal Encounters?

FatalEncounters.org is a project to create a national database of people killed by law enforcement going back to the year 2000.

We started the project because there is no adequate database for citizens, researchers or law enforcement to track trends in officer-involved homicides across regions or time.  

The 1994 Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act mandated “the Attorney General shall, through appropriate means, acquire data about the use of excessive force by law enforcement officers,” and the publication of an annual report.  This requirement has been virtually ignored for 23 years. In 2000, the federal government passed the Death in Custody Reporting Act, but it was essentially voluntary, and fewer than half of deaths were reported. In 2014, Congress reauthorized the Death in Custody Reporting Act, but again, it had no teeth.

Collecting data is the first step for analysis of police killings in the United States. The data can then be used to understand and improve the issue.  Our government knows who we call on our cell phones, who we email, and probably even the contents of those calls and emails.  So the idea that our government is unable to record the names of the people it kills, and unable to explain why, is a ridiculous and dangerous idea.  We are proving it wrong.  

2)  How do you collect the data?

We collect data from news reports, from public records requests directly from police agencies, and from court filings and legal documents.  A small percentage of our data is "crowdsourced," meaning anyone can research and submit information.  

3)  What kind of responses do you get from FOIA requests?

We’ve requested data at the federal level and in several states. The responses from law enforcement have covered the gamut, from sending the information without comment or delay, to a delayed response, to answering the request in such a way as to make the information useless, down to outright refusal to obey public records laws, defying us to sue them.  Those refusals are informative in their own way.  
 

4)  If this is crowdsourced, then why do you need money?

While we allow “the crowd” to submit information, the crowdsourced information is now less than 5 percent of the database. We pay researchers for most of the data. Funding will allow us to finish the project more quickly.  Our current resources put us on pace to finish the first draft of the database in October 2017.  
 

Fatal Encounters has already had an impact.  When we published our completed data for the years 2013 and 2014 we made a key contribution to the national conversation about police killings.  We proved that the annual total was much bigger—three times bigger—than the widely reported and accepted figures the FBI has been providing for years.  This simple but important breakthrough was driven by our research. 

The sooner we complete our database, the bigger impact we’ll have on the debate. 
 

5)  What if you're overfunded?   

We have other projects we’d like to do, like make many more public records requests, but that line item is pricey and unpredictable. If we by some chance get more funding than we ask for, we’ll apply the overage to extending the life of the project. As things stand—despite hand-wringing and grandstanding—the federal government has not funded a program to collect this information in a comprehensive manner, so it remains up to us to collect the data for the foreseeable future. 
 

6)  Do you still take volunteers?

Absolutely.  Volunteers will always be at the heart of this effort.  The government has been ignoring the need to comprehensively collect this information for a very long time, and there’s a lot of work to do.  We have volunteers out there, helping with data entry, helping with a redesign of the site, doing visualizations, doing research with the data.


7)  What can you tell from the data so far?

As an organization, our conviction has been that we will not do data analysis until the first draft of the dataset is complete for the United States going back to 2000. We've enabled news organizations, activists, universities and  law enforcement to do analysis. That said, there's some simple things that can be discerned. 

The numbers are far bigger than anybody—even us—anticipated.  When this project started in 2012, we thought we would be collecting data on about 6,000 incidents altogether.  That number is now a projected 24,000.  The higher number makes the work all that much more important.  

Statistically, we find that people of color are killed at disproportionately higher rates than their shares of the general population.  Mentally ill people are a high percentage, at least 25-30 percent, of all people killed by police.  Around 94 percent of the people who die by gunshot are men.  And law enforcement in the Western states tend to kill more people per capita than Eastern ones.   Emerging state-to-state comparisons are fascinating. 

 

8)  Aren’t you duplicating efforts with the Guardian, the Washington Post, Killed by Police, wikipedia, and other organizations doing the same thing?

We have had working relationships with all of these projects.  Both the Guardian and the Washington Post used our data to start their own databases.  All these voices are welcome and needed.  

The biggest difference between our effort and theirs is that we’re trying to gather the older data at the same time as we collect data moving forward. The older data is needed so that everyone can draw meaningful conclusions by comparing regions and deaths over time. Another huge difference is we're counting all types of deaths through police encounters. For example, the Washington Post only counts gun deaths. Fatal Encounters also counts deaths through use of stun guns, in police chases, choking deaths—whenever a police officer is present.
 

The scope, depth, discipline, potential, and open-source philosophy of Fatal Encounters remains unique.  In an May 1, 2015, front-page story the New York Times described Fatal Encounters as “the most meticulous” of all similar projects.  Media organizations around the world are using our data.  And we’re in it for the long haul.

 

9)  How does this actually help people? 

There are lots of answers to that question.  They fall into three basic ideas.
 

Simple visibility.  You cannot solve a problem until you know the size and shape of the problem.  This issue is greater and more urgent than we ever suspected.  People must know the risks of encountering police and watch their behavior around police.  This knowledge alone can save lives.  

Gathering data is the only way to understand the underlying reality about police killings.  Researchers have uncovered correlations between police killings and victims’ characteristics, geography, and how those police forces are funded and trained and managed.  Popular opinion may consider young black men to be the most vulnerable population, and that may be true, but the data shows that other groups are at risk too.  Native Americans. The deaf.  The mentally ill.  The suicidal.  Motorcyclists.  Veterans.  Policemen’s spouses. 

And accountability.  Today some police departments laugh out loud at the idea that they are responsible to the public in any way.  They operate in secret.  Our current statistics show that officers who have killed on duty, whatever the circumstances, face criminal charges in less than 1 percent of deaths.  Police often appear immune to criminal indictment, let alone conviction.  So the families of victims seek justice with their only legal recourse, civil suits.  When they're successful, civil suits can award millions to survivors, burden taxpayers, and have absolutely no effect on how police operate.  There is no working feedback loop to decrease fatal police violence.  Laying groundwork towards effective police accountability is another important use for the data we gather.    
 

With a successful crowdfunding campaign, we can make this problem visible in a way that can’t be denied.  We’ll be able to help identify best practices to support positive change.  When the best policies are in place, we’ll have fewer police killed by criminals and fewer individuals killed by police, which is the whole purpose of this project.

10)  Is my contribution tax-deductible? 

Fatal Encounters Dot Org is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization.  Our EIN (IRS tax exempt number) is 47-2263583. While we are a nonprofit, this fundraising campaign is not using  Indiegogo's nonprofit platform for logistical reasons. Particularly for larger donations, if you would like your donation to be tax-deductible, donate directly to Fatal Encounters Dot Org.
story_txt:
Fatal Encounters documents the people who have been killed by police in the United States since 2000.
Until us, nobody could say how many people are killed by police in this country.  No government authority. No lobbying group. No watchdog organization. Nobody.  Nobody could reliably describe the size or shape of fatal police violence in the U.S.  
That’s a problem.  We’re solving that problem.  That’s our mission.  

Since 2012, Fatal Encounters has been building an impartial, comprehensive, searchable national database of people killed during interactions with law enforcement at FatalEncounters.org.  Our main database is open source.  Everyone is welcome to search for names online, analyze the results, or download the entire spreadsheet for free at any time.  
 

 
Our effort has already been effective.  In 2014, during the crisis in Ferguson, Missouri, Fatal Encounters' key contribution was to show that the annual total of police killings was more than three times larger than the official numbers.  For years, the FBI has reported that between 300 and 400 people are killed by police each year. They call each death a "justifiable" homicide in their reports. Based on 2013 and 2014 data, we've proven beyond dispute that the number of people who die is closer to 1,700. 
We’re proud to move the national conversation forward.  
 

 
Other, bigger media outlets—like the Washington Post—have joined the chorus.  Their voices are welcome, but the scope, depth, discipline, potential, and open-source philosophy of Fatal Encounters remains unique.  In a May 1, 2015, front-page story the New York Times described Fatal Encounters as “the most meticulous” of all similar projects.  
 

 
We've also empowered universities and smaller organizations—even individuals—to advocate for change using our data. Samuel Sinyangwe and DeRay Mckesson use our data in their Mapping Police Violence project in support of #BlackLivesMatter. 
Even members of law enforcement uses our data. For example, in his book, In Context: Understanding Police Killings of Unarmed Civilians, Texas Police Detective Nick Selby drew extensively from our data. In a Department of Justice study published in December, FatalEncounters' data most closely exemplified the DoJ's best-practices hopes for a program that looked great--but apparently was not funded.

Some killings, like those of Michael Brown, Philando Castile, and Justine Damond, draw exhaustive coverage, and Fatal Encounters has been a part of the discussion: AlJazeera, CTGN America ... and even The Daily Show with Jon Stewart.  But the sad fact is, most killings escape public attention, retrievable only from two or three paragraphs in local newspapers.  Anybody who’s serious about drawing conclusions must first see the whole pattern.  As Senator Cory Booker pointed out when he sponsored legislation to improve tracking of police brutality: “The first step in fixing a problem is understanding the extent of the problem you have.”  When you hear it like that, it sounds obvious.  

The first draft of our database is about 94 percent complete. We've documented more than 21,800 deaths during police interactions.  At our current rate, we hope to have the draft complete in October 2017.  Our intention for the next phase of Fatal Encounters is to make the data even more useful by including data on whether the person was armed, mentally ill or a veteran. It's also our intention to add data regarding officers killed in the line of duty, so the dataset can be truly comprehensive.
Please help us push this conversation forward. Tell your friends. Share it on social media. Tell your co-workers.  We’re a 501(c)3 so donations can be tax-deductible. While we are a nonprofit, this fundraising campaign is not using  Indiegogo's nonprofit platform for logistical reasons. Particularly for larger donations, if you would like your donation to be tax-deductible, donate directly to Fatal Encounters Dot Org. You'll get all the perks that we've described here, it just won't change the total on this page. You can make a difference. 
 

 

Where Will the Money Go?In this campaign, we're trying to raise the money we need to run Fatal Encounters Dot Org for six months. The biggest portion is salary for the executive director, who is also our primary researcher and fact-checker. The rest of the funds will go to operational expenses like per-record researchers, web hosting, and government taxes and fees.   FAQ 1)  What is Fatal Encounters?FatalEncounters.org is a project to create a national database of people killed by law enforcement going back to the year 2000.We started the project because there is no adequate database for citizens, researchers or law enforcement to track trends in officer-involved homicides across regions or time.  The 1994 Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act mandated “the Attorney General shall, through appropriate means, acquire data about the use of excessive force by law enforcement officers,” and the publication of an annual report.  This requirement has been virtually ignored for 23 years. story:
In early 2016, I met Remmy Kasongo, a Congolese tailor, who, along with his wife and seven children, had spent 16 years living in a refugee camp. Remmy's family had recently been resettled in Lancaster, PA, where he remained unemployed due to his limited proficiency in English and a chronic health condition that prevented him from working most manual labor jobs.

Remmy and I began to work together, developing a collection incorporating African wax prints with designs from my company, Forager Co. The result was a beautiful blend of our cultures and skills as well as an eye opening view into the world of refugee families struggling to begin a life in a new country.

With Remmy's involvement in the design, making, and marketing of our products, he has started to acquire work experience in a new environment. He is earning income, interacting with a wide community, and learning English.  Plus, we are having a good time working as a team making and marketing our goods. 

I could see the positive impact this work could bring to refugee craftsmen like Remmy. We were excited by the products we were making and the reaction was great. With the encouragement and support of friends and customers, we created the Refugee Makers Project. 

Shortly after we started working together, the very thing I had hoped to prevent happened: Remmy took a job cleaning equipment in an industrial poultry operation, where he wore a hazmat suit + mask, and was on his knees from 3pm to 1am. This was my call to action. I decided to develop this project and to raise funds that would allow Remmy and other refugee artisans to do what they know and love. 

Our big dream is the creation of a workshop, where we hope to provide a well-equipped work space for a growing team of refugee artisans. From here, we’ll be able to take on production work for other small designers and, eventually, achieve sustainability. A few of these small designer collaborations are already in the works. Once established, we want to open our doors and invite in the community. We envision retail sales, events, and workshops.

We are inviting you to be a part of seeing these refugee makers thrive. With your support, you will be helping Remmy and others like him, and these products that showcase the mark of their maker's hands will be brought to life. The positive impact on the lives we touch will be great.

. . .

For the realization of this project, we need assistance in several areas. In exchange for this support, we’re offering up our handmade wares, some very unique experiences, and a whole lot of gratitude. Our plan is as follows:

Step 1 secures a refugee worker’s wages for one year ($28,000).

Step 2 ensures we have the funding to market our project and goods. We’ll seek to increase awareness and grow our channel of distribution and sales, allowing the Refugee Makers Project to become a sustainable business ($6,000).

Step 3 allows us to purchase goods, equipment, and supplies, among them a solid sewing machine, a quality overlock machine, a cutting table, and any other materials required to set up shop. This will increase both the productivity and growth potential of the business ($5,000).

Step 4 - our big dream - is a studio in Lancaster, PA. Our ideal workshop space would bring refugees out of their homes and into a bright space where they would acquire skills and interact with the community. Attaining this space would enable us to take on work for other small companies and it would also serve as a space to hold workshops and events for our community. ($18,000).

There is so much good that can be done. We’re asking for your support to help us build a sustainable path for these refugee makers and their families. With many thanks and much love,

Bryan, Remmy, and the Refugee Makers Project Team

Remmy and I at Field + Supply, a modern makers craft fair / Our African Wax print bags at the Brooklyn Museum shop / Indigo dying in my back yard / With the team of MakersFinders /  Collaborating with others . . .

story:
.

To know more about us, please visit: http://nocountryforwomen.org
Check out our Facebook page at: https://www.facebook.com/nocountryforwomen


If you do not know the roots of rape, how can you destroy it?


The Problem:


Every 22 minutes, there is a reported rape in India. How many go unreported?

The conversation about rape ends at sexual frustration alone; this is superficial and limits the solutions that can be generated. Many well-intentioned, highly-publicized campaigns try to feebly reassign gender roles, stating things like “Real Men Take Care Of Women” and “Real Men Don’t Rape”. While at first glance these may seem effective, they simply strengthen the social reinforcement of hypermasculinity that contributes to the problem of rape.


It is obvious that the problem of rape in India is a lot more complicated. It is also obvious that without complete knowledge of the problem, we cannot effectively tackle it.


This knowledge is often confined to academic institutions and does not enter the space of activism, where social change is actually executed. Universal access to this knowledge is inhibited by factors such as academic jargon, quality of education, critical media literacy, etc.


Our Solution:


Translating education into action.


No Country For Women bridges the divorce between the space of academia and the space of activism. We make in-depth academic understanding about the problem of rape accessible, with the express intent to translate education into action. We develop educational material that places an emphasis on analytical, critical thinking and introspective skills.


No Country For Women penetrates institutions that have traditionally maintained a culture of silence (schools, colleges, corporates) and conducts workshops regarding the sociocultural causes of rape and gender-based discrimination. We also create spaces for conversation in the physical and digital mediums by hosting conferences and events, circulating posters and visuals and sharing stories of individuals who have experienced gender-based discrimination and violence.


Our Work So Far:


1. Workshops: No Country For Women has educated over 1500 students in various schools and colleges in Bangalore, India on the relationship between gender policing and rape. The response has been overwhelmingly positive.


2. Conference: No Country For Women is hosting a day-long city-wide conference on August 23rd in Bangalore at the Leela Palace. The conference will feature in-depth discussions and analyses on the sociocultural roots of rape, as well as serve as a breeding ground for the development of effective long-term solutions. Attendees will include high school and college students, Human Resources professionals, psychologists, academics, activists, NGO representatives, corporate executives and more. By bringing together people from diverse walks of society, we hope to collapse the logistical barriers that become hurdles to interdisciplinary thought and action.


3. Video Content: A mini-documentary about our work went viral (the video included above), amassing around 850,000+ views and 100,000+ shares in a week. The video explains the relationship between gender policing and rape, and initiated national discourse about the same.


4. Social Art: No Country For Women is producing images with thought-provoking quotes intended to spark conversations. These posters are circulated digitally and placed around the city to kickstart a social art campaign. You can see some of these posters in the image tab of the campaign.


No Country For Women in the media:


No Country For Women has been featured in numerous national and international publications, including Borgen Project and Policy Mic (USA), The Hindu, DNA India, Deccan Chronicle, Bangalore Times, Deccan Herald, Your Story, Social Story and Youth Ki Awaaz among others. You can see more details here: http://nocountryforwomen.org/media


Future Directions:


No Country For Women has been invited to conduct workshops and organize events and talks all over the country. These include: TEDxLSR, Harvard-India Initiative, Coalescence (entrepreneurial summit at BITS-Pilani), Kshitij (IIT Kharagpur’s Techno-Management fest), Festember (NIT Trichy’s social and cultural fest) among others. We have been asked to partner with Social Development and Women’s Development Cells of colleges all over India and are in the process of developing long-term relationships with research institutions, NGOs and the education sector.



Why This Campaign:


We have been fortunate enough to receive fantastic national support so far. However, to expand and sustain our campaign, we need funding.


We plan to do the following with our funds:


1. Workshop toolkit: We will develop a comprehensive curriculum that transforms relevant social analysis into accessible educational material and will spark effective action. It will contain worksheets, presentation slides, examples, original studies we cite, pedagogical tools and activities and our own general guidelines on what we notice works in the classroom. We are already building a network within which to distribute this.


2. Expansion: We would like to take the campaign all over India and already have set plans for expansion in Delhi (and NCR), Mumbai, Andhra Pradesh, West Bengal, Gujarat and Orissa.


3. Partner with Teach For India: We will partner with TFI and train their volunteers to give our workshops. This way we will ensure our material is also made accessible to underprivileged students.


4. Volunteer training: We will train and certify volunteers to give our workshops and talks.


5. Conferences and events: We will organize more city-wide and national conferences and events to create spaces where mass-awareness can be spread and effective solutions can be brainstormed. These spaces will allow individuals from different parts of society to come together and work in conjunction to make changes.


6. Social Art campaigns: We will launch several national social art campaigns where we circulate images and stories from people about everyday gender-based discrimination and violence. This will give people a platform to voice themselves and be heard.


7. Bringing together individuals and organizations: We will facilitate relationships between individuals and organizations in diverse walks of society to create a self-sustainable community of changemakers with diverse strengths, who can add to solution-making in different ways.


About Us:


No Country For Women is run by three Brown University undergraduates - Shreena Thakore, Ria Vaidya and Rishabh Singh. Growing up in India, they experienced various forms of gender-based discrimination. Upon gaining the relevant analytical tools in college, they decided enough was enough. They were awarded a Davis Projects For Peace fellowship to carry out a social justice campaign of their own design and that’s how No Country For Women was born.


Other Ways You Can Help:


1. Spread the word! Share our website and Facebook to anyone that may be interested.


2. Invite us! If you know of a school/college/workplace that might benefit from a workshop, let us know!


3. Spark conversation! Notice how everyday seemingly innocent objects contribute to an overall culture of rape. Speak out next time you hear someone say “boys will be boys” or see a problematic commercial.


4. Email us! So we can figure out other collaborative possibilities
story_txt:
.To know more about us, please visit: http://nocountryforwomen.orgCheck out our Facebook page at: https://www.facebook.com/nocountryforwomenIf you do not know the roots of rape, how can you destroy it?The Problem:Every 22 minutes, there is a reported rape in India. How many go unreported?The conversation about rape ends at sexual frustration alone; this is superficial and limits the solutions that can be generated. Many well-intentioned, highly-publicized campaigns try to feebly reassign gender roles, stating things like “Real Men Take Care Of Women” and “Real Men Don’t Rape”. While at first glance these may seem effective, they simply strengthen the social reinforcement of hypermasculinity that contributes to the problem of rape.It is obvious that the problem of rape in India is a lot more complicated. It is also obvious that without complete knowledge of the problem, we cannot effectively tackle it.This knowledge is often confined to academic institutions and does not enter the space of activism, where social change is actually executed. Universal access to this knowledge is inhibited by factors such as academic jargon, quality of education, critical media literacy, etc.Our Solution:Translating education into action.No Country For Women bridges the divorce between the space of academia and the space of activism. We make in-depth academic understanding about the problem of rape accessible, with the express intent to translate education into action. We develop educational material that places an emphasis on analytical, critical thinking and introspective skills.No Country For Women penetrates institutions that have traditionally maintained a culture of silence (schools, colleges, corporates) and conducts workshops regarding the sociocultural causes of rape and gender-based discrimination. We also create spaces for conversation in the physical and digital mediums by hosting conferences and events, circulating posters and visuals and sharing stories of individuals who have experienced gender-based discrimination and violence.Our Work So Far:1. Workshops: No Country For Women has educated over 1500 students in various schools and colleges in Bangalore, India on the relationship between gender policing and rape. The response has been overwhelmingly positive.2. Conference: No Country For Women is hosting a day-long city-wide conference on August 23rd in Bangalore at the Leela Palace. The conference will feature in-depth discussions and analyses on the sociocultural roots of rape, as well as serve as a breeding ground for the development of effective long-term solutions. Attendees will include high school and college students, Human Resources professionals, psychologists, academics, activists, NGO representatives, corporate executives and more. By bringing together people from diverse walks of society, we hope to collapse the logistical barriers that become hurdles to interdisciplinary thought and action.3. Video Content: A mini-documentary about our work went viral (the video included above), amassing around 850,000+ views and 100,000+ shares in a week. The video explains the relationship between gender policing and rape, and initiated national discourse about the same.4. Social Art: No Country For Women is producing images with thought-provoking quotes intended to spark conversations. These posters are circulated digitally and placed around the city to kickstart a social art campaign. You can see some of these posters in the image tab of the campaign.
No Country For Women in the media:No Country For Women has been featured in numerous national and international publications, including Borgen Project and Policy Mic (USA), The Hindu, DNA India, Deccan Chronicle, Bangalore Times, Deccan Herald, Your Story, Social Story and Youth Ki Awaaz among others. You can see more details here: http://nocountryforwomen.org/mediaFuture Directions:No Country For Women has been invited to conduct workshops and organize events and talks all over the country. These include: TEDxLSR, Harvard-India Initiative, Coalescence (entrepreneurial summit at BITS-Pilani), Kshitij (IIT Kharagpur’s Techno-Management fest), Festember (NIT Trichy’s social and cultural fest) among others. We have been asked to partner with Social Development and Women’s Development Cells of colleges all over India and are in the process of developing long-term relationships with research institutions, NGOs and the education sector.Why This Campaign:We have been fortunate enough to receive fantastic national support so far. However, to expand and sustain our campaign, we need funding.We plan to do the following with our funds:1. Workshop toolkit: We will develop a comprehensive curriculum that transforms relevant social analysis into accessible educational material and will spark effective action. It will contain worksheets, presentation slides, examples, original studies we cite, pedagogical tools and activities and our own general guidelines on what we notice works in the classroom. We are already building a network within which to distribute this. 2. Expansion: We would like to take the campaign all over India and already have set plans for expansion in Delhi (and NCR), Mumbai, Andhra Pradesh, West Bengal, Gujarat and Orissa.3. Partner with Teach For India: We will partner with TFI and train their volunteers to give our workshops. This way we will ensure our material is also made accessible to underprivileged students.4. Volunteer training: We will train and certify volunteers to give our workshops and talks.5. Conferences and events: We will organize more city-wide and national conferences and events to create spaces where mass-awareness can be spread and effective solutions can be brainstormed. These spaces will allow individuals from different parts of society to come together and work in conjunction to make changes.6. Social Art campaigns: We will launch several national social art campaigns where we circulate images and stories from people about everyday gender-based discrimination and violence. This will give people a platform to voice themselves and be heard.7. Bringing together individuals and organizations: We will facilitate relationships between individuals and organizations in diverse walks of society to create a self-sustainable community of changemakers with diverse strengths, who can add to solution-making in different ways.About Us:No Country For Women is run by three Brown University undergraduates - Shreena Thakore, Ria Vaidya and Rishabh Singh. Growing up in India, they experienced various forms of gender-based discrimination. Upon gaining the relevant analytical tools in college, they decided enough was enough. They were awarded a Davis Projects For Peace fellowship to carry out a social justice campaign of their own design and that’s how No Country For Women was born.Other Ways You Can Help:1. Spread the word! Share our website and Facebook to anyone that may be interested.2. Invite us! If you know of a school/college/workplace that might benefit from a workshop, let us know!3. Spark conversation! Notice how everyday seemingly innocent objects contribute to an overall culture of rape. Speak out next time you hear someone say “boys will be boys” or see a problematic commercial. 4. Email us! So we can figure out other collaborative possibilities

story: My name is Peggy Lester.  I’m posting this campaign on behalf of my brother, Marty Griffin.  In September of 2008, my brother was wrongfully convicted of rape and sentenced to 25 years in prison with no possibility of parole and will be on probation for LIFE, which is absolutely insane! Yes, he did have "consensual sex" with the so called “victim”, but lies were told, bruises were faked, & so forth. The doctor’s video deposition stated there was no bruising, redness, tears, cuts, or any markings that would indicate rape occurred. There were even a couple of statements given by the “victim” which were inconsistent with each other. Several law enforcement officials didn’t believe that "rape" had occurred!! During the trial in September of 2008, the district attorney’s office offered a plea of false imprisonment and 365 days in jail with time served and drop the rape charge, as they felt they didn’t have a case & my brother even turned down that plea offer because he said he was NOT GUILTY and  would die and go to hell before he pled guilty to ANY of the charges against him. How can people get away with lying on others and have them convicted  of crimes they honestly didn’t commit?! Shouldn’t the “victim” and witnesses be convicted of perjury?! Since conviction, the “victim” has been disowned by several of her family members b/c they don't believe she was raped. Anybody that really and truly knows my brother and his heart, knows that he would NEVER commit a crime of this nature!!! He has a 5 year old niece and a 3 and a half year old nephew that he’s never met.  He has seen pictures of them and talked to them on the phone and of course loves them to death. My daughter asks all the time, “mama when can Uncle Marty come to my house, where is Uncle Marty, can I go to Uncle Marty’s house?” Hearing my daughter ask my brother when he’s coming to see her truly tears my heart into a million pieces and to know the love my children have for an uncle that unfortunately they’ve been unable to meet.  This is the kind of love our family has for each other..... Unfortunately, we have exhausted all possibilities in coming up with funds to hire legal counsel to take the case back to court. With all this being said, I am asking for any amount of contributions to please help with legal fees to hire a defense attorney to take the case back to court. If you would like to contribute, please visit the site at www.indiegogo.com.  Scroll to the bottom and click on BROWSE to search for the campaign and then search for Marty’s Defense Fund by typing in the search box next to Start Your Campaign. Forms of payment accepted are debit and credit card or you can pay through PayPal. PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD & SHARE THE CAMPAIGN. THANK YOU IN ADVANCE & MAY GOD BLESS...

story:
Inside the Black Triangle 

The black triangle was a symbol used in Nazi Germany to categorize atypical behavior which included queer women. In the '60's and '70's feminists and lesbians reclaimed the symbol as a sign of solidarity and pride. 

Rachael Zimmerman began a photojournalist series two years ago with the intention to share the struggles, joy, heartbreak, confusion and diverse experiences of  queer women living in a heteronormative world. Sharing stories leads to relatability, compassion and hopefully acceptance. Not only is empathy necessary outside the LGBTQ community, but now more than ever, equality is needed within the community.

In the past two years Inside the Black Triangle has evolved into a safe community for women to connect and support each other. 

The 2018 Limited Edition Pride Shirt will be sold both online and at Denver Pride. Let's continue to support each other while reclaiming unwanted stigmas and stereotypes. It's the LGBTQ community's responsibility to lead by example and treat each other equally.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Natasha and I am 26 years old medical assistant. I consider myself a member of the global cannabis culture over the last ten years, because being one doesn’t mean just smoking weed – it goes much wider. I joined cannabis activism in 2014 and since then I have been working with different associations, organizations and individuals on educating about cannabis. 15 months ago I started my own project too, called Domacica – First Serbian Cannabis Vlog, you might check it on the following link.

In the past four years I gained great experience and met many relevant people. I would especially point out successful cooperation I had with:

 

Museum of Vojvodina,  Department: Agricultural museum

Institute of Field and Vegetable Crops, Department: Alternative crops

Famous cannabis activists Dr. Robert Melamede and Mr. Marc Emery

Serbian public figures Bvana Herbalajzer, Lucano Hillfinger, Prti Bee Gee and Marko Vidojković

VICE Serbia

and great guys from Beograd na Vutri and Najnaduvaniji lik in creating documentaries about growing and processing hemp, medical understanding of cannabis and cannabis culture.

Also:

IRKA- The initiative to change the cannabis legislation - The first and the biggest cannabis association in Serbia that has been organizing the most of seminars, debates, public meetings and workshops about all sorts of cannabis and their potentials. With an impressive collection of public testimonies regarding curing with cannabis, IRKA conducted a major impact in changing public opinion about cannabis. As a member of IRKA’s working group I have gained a rich experience in organizing public appearances and learned a big part of what I know about cannabis today.

HUK - Serbian HEMP association.that promotes the hemp industry and  actively provides worthy knowledge in the field of agriculture.

and other organizations, entrepreneurs and artists whose work is cannabis-related (LEKALIZACIJA Srbije, Udruženje Konoplja, Gramina, Hemp Packs, Stereo Banana and many others).

*

Serbia obviously has very developed cannabis culture and a significant number of people here is very interested in preserving it. However, there is a big resistance for cannabis market here because we have the parts of society which are very traditional and ready for necessary actions. Basically, decriminalization of cannabis is the only thing that wouldn’t hurt anyone and that can help many people to continue with their work and life safely, happily, healthy and with dignity.

Our chances for a success in decriminalization are very high at this point, we only have one demand and people are ready to support us now more then ever. Our authorities are also ready to reconsider their policy , they prove us that through the last couple of years. So, now it’s up to us to show how peaceful and magnificent our community is.

 

After many long brainstorms we created a 6- point program to  highlight the benefits of decriminalization and these are subjects:

1. Cannabis legislation

2. Cannabis (and) culture

3. Medical use of cannabis

4. Industrial and economical benefits of cannabis

5. Non-medical (recreational) use of cannabis

6. Special guests of event

 

Speakers are my great coworkers, mostly from IRKA, who already have superknowledge about cannabis and a lot of experience in public lecturing. Let me present you some of them: Simić Miloš, Danica Petrović, Gradimir Veljković, Maja Vasić, Romana Klem, Vukašin Krstić and many others, with a big help of our expert-associates from different spheres such as law, economy and medicine. 

Special guests of event will be cannabis activists from region (Macedonia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Slovenia, Bulgaria..) and Serbian public figures (writers, comedians, musicians etc.) that announced us a support with their public performance.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Cannabis March, Sebia 2018 need 3000$ to be realized. Here are costs:

  • Stage: 400$
  • Sound system and microphones: 200$
  • Educational and promotional material: 500$
  • Special promotional material (flags and balloons): 300$
  • Bureaucratic costs: 200$
  • Shirts for security: 100$
  • The rest of money goes for internet marketing, IndieGoGo and eventual unplanned costs

In this situation, more money means higher public reach and we want it HIGHest possible. Starting from Serbia we would like to spread the story about decriminalization of cannabis through the whole world. So, once Cannabis March is over our activities don’t stop. All photo, video and audio materials we’d create during the event will be used for making brief inspirational videos and stories about cannabis we want to send worldwide.

 

The Impact

The current situation led us to the point where withdrawal is not an option, neither offence is. We want to prove that being cannabis activist means being brave,  peaceful, with dignity and that we are ready for making compromises and agreements. We want to show that we are not afraid and that our colleagues should not be as well, no matter where on the planet they live.

It is of great importance for all cannabis communities in the world to know that we mustn’t step out from accomplishing our basic human rights and that only united and through mutual support  we can make some changes.

 

Risks & Challenges

Three things can make this event to be realized by backup plan:

  1. Authorities wouldn’t give us permission for making public gathering
    -This has never happened before and if happens March will be considered in Social Cannabis Club Belgrade.
  2. Nobody shows up
    -Also never happened, because we have at least 100 people that always support our activities.

  3. We don’t get enough money
    -We already have enough money for basic appearance, we just want it to be perfect. And with your help it could be usefull not just for Serbia, but for many other countrys.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cant help us with money – there is stil way to help us! Use Indiegogo share tools and reveal this project to people who could contribute us. We appriciate everybodys goodwill to be helpfull.

story:
Short Summary

Two cousins in India were raped and murdered recently when they went out to the fields to defecate because they had no indoor toilet. 

Having to go is a basic human function, so having a safe, clean place to go should be a basic human right. 

A total of 2.5 billion people worldwide don't have access to a safe, clean toilet, forcing them to defecate in the open. That is not only humiliating for them, it also spreads disease and can be dangerous for women. 

I spearheaded the production of The Potty Project video to raise awareness and funds to build more toilets in India. I chose to focus our efforts on India because it tops the world's nations in lacking toilets. 

The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation is already doing active work in this area in India and we want to help.

Any donation is valuable and welcome. If you can't donate, please help us raise awareness by watching our video and sharing it with your community.

Thank you!

story:
I have been an Amazon jungle tour guide for over 15 years and am the originator, Consulting Producer, and main character of The Travel Channel's TV series Hotel Amazon.

Since my early days in the jungle I would deliver as many Malaria nets that my pockets and friends could purchase, yet more were always needed.  Then when I started filming Hotel Amazon I suspended net delivery because I became so busy. Then KARMA got the best of me, I contracted Malaria.  I never felt worse in my life and would not wish it on my worse enemy.  I then vowed that I will do all I can to provide as many nets to children as possible.

This first phase will be a Malaria net deliver in the Belen District of Iquitos, Peru.  Belen is home to some 65,000 people, most of them poor, and many of whom live in extreme poverty with no clean water, proper sanitation, nor electric power distribution. 90% of homes house two or more families; some homes as many as five.

Most homes either float or are built on stilts, as the river level rises 15–30 feet throughout the year. Currently the water level is peaking to overflow capacity and in May it will start receding and that is when the trouble will start.

The standing water left behind is prime breeding ground for mosquitoes.  Is such a underdeveloped and populated area as Belen, Malaria and even Dengue Fever (another mosquito born virus) will run rampant.  With your help the children of Belen can be protected during this dangerous time of year and use the net for years to come.

During the Malaria net deliveries I will be using my TV experience to provide donors with LIVE Stream video tours of Belen (Via Facebook) and interview the children we are helping. I will also film the entire process which will be  produced into a video for the donors, and school children to learn more about Malaria, different cultures and societies.   

The funds will be used for Malaria nets, travel expense, and food.  We have many incredible perks for your generosity.  If we do not meet or surpass our goal I will still make that best of what I have and continue fighting to protect children from Malaria. 


It is a simple way to directly save lives.

I hope you will please join me on this life saving mission and together we can protect more and more children of the world from Malaria.

Feel free to contact me with any questions or interviews.

Sincerely,
Rusty Johnson
Rusty@RustyJohnson.tv
www.RustyJohnson.tv
845-430-8306
