story:
Türkçe için sayfanın en altına inin. (Scroll down for Turkish.)

Istanbul LGBTI+ Pride Week celebrates its 26th anniversary!

Istanbul Pride Week, organised with the collective efforts of volunteers, who gather with open calls will take place this year 25 June- 1 July 2018.

Istanbul Pride has brought up various themes including “Beware of the Family!”, “Taboo”, “Memory”, “Contact”, “Normal?” and “We Unite!” in the last years. Once again this year, in addition to the the forums, panel discussions and events addressing issues such as health, visibility, and constitutional rights central to agenda of the LGBTI+ movement, we will also discuss how we can build a political sense of solidarity and how we can find alternative ways to achieve this, despite the state of emergency and oppression becoming more of a menace every single day.

To reach out each other, to heal our wounds, and to talk about our experiences, bodies, and emotions, we will come together at workshops, and we will celebrate our solidarity in parties. Just like every year, we will vote and elect this year’s hate speech champions among your nominations at the 14th "Genetically Modified Tomatoes" ceremony. We will extend our rebellion with our comrades coming from other cities for the Pride Week. We will continue to spread throughout the city and shout out loud that "we are here" with our stencils and our annual exhibition, which is organised with an open call to artists and through consensus.

Last year we reacted to the ban on our march by dispersing into every corner of Istanbul with glitter, confetti and rainbow flags, reading our press statements. We raised our voice not only on Istiklal Street but on every place and every space possible to make ourselves to be heard. From this point on, in the face of the every obstacle put on our way, every problem that makes our lives harder, we will continue to react even more creatively than ever before. We are not giving up on the streets, we are not letting any kind of fear to scare us away. We are here, we are not leaving, and get used to it!

We are waiting for your donations for the expenses of this week-long organisation that is put together with a collective solidarity without any funds granted:

• Travel and accommodation expenses for the local LGBTI+ organisations coming from all across Turkey

• Travel and accommodation for the panelists

• Communication/Press expenses (i.e. social media, website hosts) 

• Genetically Modified Tomato Awards (i.e. production, décor, video recordings and editings)

• Event expenses (i.e. security, fees for some event spaces if necessary)

• Pride Week Exhibition (exhibition setup)

 

*In the first descriptive title, we couldn't add "+" to "LGBTI" that we added a year ago to celebrate every kind of romantic/sexual orientation because of Indiegogo's interface structure, We are still working on that problem to solve it. 

 

❀❀❀

 

İstanbul LGBTİ+ Onur Haftası bu yıl 26 yaşında!

Her sene yapılan açık çağrılarla bir araya gelen gönüllü grubunun kolektif katkılarıyla hazırlanan Onur Haftası 25 Haziran- 1 Temmuz 2018 tarihlerinde gerçekleşecek.

Şimdiye kadar “Dikkat Aile Var!”, “Tabu”, “Bellek”, “Direniş”, “Temas”, “Normal?” temalarıyla şekillenen Onur Haftası'nda hafta boyunca LGBTİ+ hareketinin gündemini oluşturan sağlık, görünürlük ve anayasal haklar gibi konularda yaptığımız forumlar, paneller ve etkinliklere ek olarak, OHAL'e ve her gün artan baskılara rağmen nasıl politik bir aradalığı örebileceğimizi, bunun için nasıl alternatif yollar bulabileceğimizi konuşacağız.

Birbirimize dokunmak, yaralarımızı sarmak, güvenli alanlar oluşturarak deneyimlerimizi, bedenlerimizi ve duygularımızı konuşabilmek için atölyelerde, bir aradalığımızı kutlamak için partilerde buluşacağız. Bu sene de 14. Hormonlu Domates Ödülleri ile bu yılın nefret söylemlerini sizin belirlediğiniz adaylarla oylamaya sunarak seçecek, hafta boyunca yapılacak partiler ile her şehirden İstanbul LGBTI+ Onur Haftası için gelen yüzlerce kişiyle beraber eğlenerek varoluşumuzu kutlamaya, isyanımızı güçlendirmeye devam edeceğiz. Her sene yine açık çağrı ve konsensusla içeriğini oluşturduğumuz sergimizle ve stensillerimizle şehre dağılmaya, hala burada olduğumuzu bağırmaya devam edeceğiz.

Geçtiğimiz sene yürüyüşlerimize gelen yasaklamalara tepkimizi İstanbul’un her bir köşesine simlerle, konfetilerle, gökkuşağı bayraklarıyla dağılarak, basın açıklamamızı okuyarak gösterdik. Sözümüzü sadece İstiklal Caddesi üzerinde değil, bulunduğumuz her noktada ve sesimizi duyurabildiğimiz her alanda söyledik. Bundan sonra da önümüze çıkarılan her engelde ve hayatımızı zorlaştıran her sorunda bir öncekinden daha farklı ve daha yaratıcı olarak tepkimizi ortaya koymaya devam edeceğiz. Sokakları da caddeleri de bırakmıyor, hiçbir korkunun bizi hizaya sokmasına izin vermiyoruz. Buradayız, alışın, gitmiyoruz!

Kolektif bir dayanışma ile fon alınmadan hazırlanan bu hafta içerisinde bazı masraflarımız için herkesin desteğini bekliyoruz:

• Türkiye'nin dört bir yanından gelen LGBTİ+ yerel örgütlerinden gelecek kişilerin ulaşım ve konaklama masrafları

• Panel Katılımcılarının ulaşım ve konaklama masrafları

• İletişim/Basın harcamaları (Sosyal medya, websitesi sağlayıcıları)

• Hormonlu Domates Ödül Töreni (Prodüksiyon, dekor, video çekimleri)
story_txt:
Türkçe için sayfanın en altına inin. (Scroll down for Turkish.)
Istanbul LGBTI+ Pride Week celebrates its 26th anniversary!
Istanbul Pride Week, organised with the collective efforts of volunteers, who gather with open calls will take place this year 25 June- 1 July 2018.
Istanbul Pride has brought up various themes including “Beware of the Family!”, “Taboo”, “Memory”, “Contact”, “Normal?” and “We Unite!” in the last years. Once again this year, in addition to the the forums, panel discussions and events addressing issues such as health, visibility, and constitutional rights central to agenda of the LGBTI+ movement, we will also discuss how we can build a political sense of solidarity and how we can find alternative ways to achieve this, despite the state of emergency and oppression becoming more of a menace every single day.
To reach out each other, to heal our wounds, and to talk about our experiences, bodies, and emotions, we will come together at workshops, and we will celebrate our solidarity in parties. Just like every year, we will vote and elect this year’s hate speech champions among your nominations at the 14th "Genetically Modified Tomatoes" ceremony. We will extend our rebellion with our comrades coming from other cities for the Pride Week. We will continue to spread throughout the city and shout out loud that "we are here" with our stencils and our annual exhibition, which is organised with an open call to artists and through consensus.
Last year we reacted to the ban on our march by dispersing into every corner of Istanbul with glitter, confetti and rainbow flags, reading our press statements. From this point on, in the face of the every obstacle put on our way, every problem that makes our lives harder, we will continue to react even more creatively than ever before. • Communication/Press expenses (i.e. social media, website hosts) 
• Genetically Modified Tomato Awards (i.e. production, décor, video recordings and editings)
• Event expenses (i.e. security, fees for some event spaces if necessary)

story:
Hello!

White Rose Faction is a fledgling team of activists & educators who want to produce online video-essays, audio-commentaries and discussions for anti-racist organizers & activists.

We've experimented with borrowing the hardware we need, but it's been either not suitable, or we've had the offer of help withdrawn.

Frankly, we're all absolutely broke right now - £150 would let us purchase a decent microphone, with a few quid left over for things we may have overlooked.

We understand that times are tight for many people right now, & that there are many worthwhile causes & campaigns that you could support.

If you've got £5 to spare, we'd really appreciate you helping us in advance - and we'd be able to get cracking with recording our material.

With your help, we'll be able to get out of this false-start & get out our first few videos as soon as possible.

Thanks so much for checking us out -- the White Rose Faction

/ agitate / educate / organize

161

story:
Skip a coffee (or 3 if you're feeling extra sacrificial) and support life today!

Imagine a show on network television that not only dismantled the arguments of the pro-death, but also did so in a winsome way that could be watched by believers and unbelieving friends and family alike. Making clear the value of the unborn child, while laying the foundation for the Gospel to be shared. Drawing a blank? We are launching a show to change that. From the director of Life Is Best, Adrian Rink, and the leading pro-life apologist in the nation, Scott Klusendorf, comes a pro-life series like you have never seen before.We are going to tackle issues like:

- Bodily Autonomy
- Life of the Mother
- Adoption
- Those who are ignorant vs those who are opposed
- Sidewalk Counseling
- Post-Abortion Redemption
- And so much more!

We know this is incredibly valuable content. And with your help, we can make it available for everyone to watch free! Equip your church, equip your family, and equip yourself in the battle for the unborn. Are you ready to defend life?

Life with Scott will be a multi-episode docuseries answering questions around the life issue, providing arguments against abortion, and engaging with the death culture on relevant, current issues.

Watch as Scott Klusendorf, founder and president of Life Training Institute, interacts with students on college campuses about the Life issue.  Hear the answers to abortion arguments from Pro-Life experts like Megan Almon and Jannique Stewart.  Watch as pastors give practical advice and personal answers to people with abortions in their past or who are considering abortion in their futures.

Life with Scott will cover major topics like:

  • the objectivity of morality
  • the best flavor of ice cream
  • the difference between an unborn fetus and a 2 year old
  • Why S.L.E.D.s are so important to the Pro-Life proponents

Life with Scott is a huge undertaking that will require partnership with YOU!  Drawing together components from so many sources will allow us to create a resource that will encourage pro-life experts, educate pro-life initiates, and explain our positions to pro-abortion advocates.

We need:

  • Your prayers!
  • Financial support for filming interviews with multiple pastors and pro-life experts and interactions with college students.
  • Support on social media as you share this project with your friends, families, and churches.

Our desire is that Life with Scott will be viewed by at least 3 people, though 3,000,000 would be even better.  We will be partnering with multiple pro-life organizations to get the news of this project out.  The best advertisement, though, will be you telling your friends and family about the series.  Share it on Facebook, Twitter, or in person to help us create a grassroots movement around this project.

Our base goal of $30,000 will allow us to make and distribute the entire first season, 13-20 episodes, of Life with Scott freely to all.  If we are able to exceed our goal amount, we have several stretch goals:

  • $50,000 - A PDF group discussion guide will be provided to go along with the show that allows school classes, Bible study groups, and families to use this in a formal education setting.
  • $85,000 - We will do commentary videos on the raw footage with Scott Klusendorf. This will allow more opportunities for education on how to speak on behalf of the unborn in the public square.
  • $120,000 - We will begin to plan out and commit to a second season of Life with Scott to be available in 2021.

We are very excited about all the possibilities and opportunities that are available for this show to make an impact on culture today.  Please prayerfully consider supporting this show as a resource that will help you, your family, your church, and the generations to come plead on behalf of the lives of the unborn.

story:
My name is Eleanna Malafouri and I am 26 year old.
I am from Greece and although I am currently residing in Sweden, I am highly sensitised by the immense migration flows of our times.
In an era of total political abstinence and inability to take action, the civil society, both in Greece but as well as in a transnational level has risen in the aid of those who are in need.
Refugees, mainly from tormented Syria as well as other long-suffering countries seek shelter under the wings of Europe, whose political sphere seems to ignore their cries for help.
On the other hand, many activist organisations hand in hand with volunteering individuals are giving their own battle in order to comfort the best way they can our tormented fellows and their families.

Being unable, at the moment, to practically help, Ι created this crowd-funding to raise awareness and indirectly aid practical activists that toil away in Lesvos with persistence and determination.

I invoke everyone's compassion for the tormented families of refugees and hope that my action will achieve its goal in order to relieve somewhat all the volunteering efforts in Lesvos and create better living conditions for the thousands of suffering souls until they get back on their feet and follow their dreams for a peaceful future.

The funding will be sent to lesvosvolunteers.com and other volunteering teams in need,  in order to provide food, clothing  and  accommodation.

My goal is to raise 2000 euros  and distribute it immediately to all volunteers  aiding at Lesvos island and other regions in need.  Taking into account the urgency of the situation, this crowd-funding will be taking place for the next 20 days. If the goal is not reached by then, all donations will be refunded.
Not everyone is able to contribute by donating money and that is completely understandable!
Spreading the word, though, by sharing this page is more valuable than you can imagine and it will most definitely make a difference!
Otherwise, if you are interested in partaking, you could also follow http://lesvosvolunteers.com and learn about alternative actions!

Thank you for supporting this cause and may you be blessed with the same compassion if ever in need.

Sincerely,

Eleanna

story:
Hi. My name is Asad and I go by they/them pronouns.

I’m a Communication & Design major at Habib University, a liberal arts college in Karachi.
In Fall 2017, I took an amazing course called Feminism and Visual Culture that, for me, opened up the possibility of using feminist texts and art to introspect my own relationships with my significant other, my body, land and identity.

The product of the course was my artist’s book, Gustakh.

Gustakh’s title is inspired by a poem Manto, written by Majeed Amjad, in which he calls Saadat Hasan Manto a gustakh — a person who transgresses norm, convention, defiant of authority, disobedient to orders and disruptive to the order of society. A gustakh is daring, and not necessarily appealing to the population that gives in to the order, and conventional, naturalized ways of living.

A work in progress, Gustakh currently consists of my autoethnography — seven meditations coupled with photographs at appropriate intervals in print, exploring how I maneuver in a postcolonial, heteropatriarchal setting, which is body- and sex-negative, hyper-consumerist, favors elitism and other structural inequalities.

The gustakhi is the attempt to redefine love outside the heterosexual imagination through living experience rather than simply ideals. The art book is a coming together of critical writing and visual narratives, engaging with the politics of sexual identity to explore and produce new ways of seeing and imagining queer lives in the global south.

I am truly honored to be offered a place at Queer Asia Conference 2018, at SOAS, University of London, to share Gustakh with the world this June.

How this conference will help me

Queer Asia is an inter-Asia collaboration, dialogue and research on issues affecting people who self-identify as LGBTQ+ or belong to other non-normative sexualities and gender identities in Asia, or Asian diasporas and beyond. It welcomes queer identifying scholars, academics, activists, artists and performers to present their work.

Queer Asia Conference 2018 is my chance to meet more gustakh and explore the potential of Gustakh as a publication for queer people to move away from the influences of the superstructures on how we live, how we love and how we write and tell our stories, and write, show and tell our stories truly our own terms, far from the heterosexual imagination, as a critique of capitalistic failure to acknowledge and accommodate queer people in their real realities.

The conference is also my opportunity to connect and receive critique from queer scholars, which is essential for this project to flourish.

How this will benefit my community

This is new work that will emerge out of Pakistan where the Western hegemonic, queer narrative does not receive the inquiry and critique it deserves, but rather is accepted among queer people who use this Western lens to make sense of their own identities, their bodies and desires. The dominant discourse on queer people in Pakistan is Orientalist. Sociology, anthropology and art, when combined, have the potential to subvert dominant discourses and open up new queer possibilities — Gustakh is first of its kind.

Discipline, in the literal sense, is to abide by the rules, not crossing boundary, while Gustakh is an interdisciplinary disruption, taking scholarship and visual culture critically to do some dismantling, for the living subjectivities of the queers in the global south to rise.

How you can help

While the conference has no registration fee, I cannot afford to travel to the UK and present it.

I’m currently in my third year at Habib University, dependent entirely on financial aid and generous donors who have paid for my admission and payable fee to get here. While it’s great to receive a better education than I can ever afford, my financial status does not allow me to travel and pursue opportunities of presenting my work.

Gustakh’s selection for Queer Asia Conference 2018 at SOAS, University of London is beyond my wildest imagination. The book is the manifestation of my ‘failed’ body as I’ve always been treated as, and the love I’ve always been told to hide.

I would be extremely grateful to you, if you could fund this journey.

Expenses

Round-trip airfare: $1000*

A̶c̶c̶o̶m̶m̶o̶d̶a̶t̶i̶o̶n̶:̶ ̶$̶1̶0̶0̶0̶** Found a host!

S̶t̶a̶n̶d̶a̶r̶d̶ ̶U̶K̶ ̶V̶i̶s̶a̶ ̶a̶p̶p̶l̶i̶c̶a̶t̶i̶o̶n̶:̶ ̶$̶1̶2̶5̶ Raised!

Food: $250

H̶e̶a̶l̶t̶h̶ ̶i̶n̶s̶u̶r̶a̶n̶c̶e̶:̶ ̶$̶1̶0̶ Raised!

Travel: $100

Total expense: $1,350

* The flight and accommodation costs are estimated to adjust the changes in exchange rate, flight and Airbnb cost over time.

** The accommodation cost could be crossed out if someone is willing to host me.

The gustakhi is the attempt to redefine love outside the heterosexual imagination through living experience rather than simply ideals. The art book is a coming together of critical writing and visual narratives, engaging with the politics of sexual identity to explore and produce new ways of seeing and imagining queer lives in the global south.
I am truly honored to be offered a place at Queer Asia Conference 2018, at SOAS, University of London, to share Gustakh with the world this June.
How this conference will help me
Queer Asia is an inter-Asia collaboration, dialogue and research on issues affecting people who self-identify as LGBTQ+ or belong to other non-normative sexualities and gender identities in Asia, or Asian diasporas and beyond. It welcomes queer identifying scholars, academics, activists, artists and performers to present their work.
Queer Asia Conference 2018 is my chance to meet more gustakh and explore the potential of Gustakh as a publication for queer people to move away from the influences of the superstructures on how we live, how we love and how we write and tell our stories, and write, show and tell our stories truly our own terms, far from the heterosexual imagination, as a critique of capitalistic failure to acknowledge and accommodate queer people in their real realities.
The conference is also my opportunity to connect and receive critique from queer scholars, which is essential for this project to flourish.
How this will benefit my community
This is new work that will emerge out of Pakistan where the Western hegemonic, queer narrative does not receive the inquiry and critique it deserves, but rather is accepted among queer people who use this Western lens to make sense of their own identities, their bodies and desires. The dominant discourse on queer people in Pakistan is Orientalist. Sociology, anthropology and art, when combined, have the potential to subvert dominant discourses and open up new queer possibilities — Gustakh is first of its kind.
Discipline, in the literal sense, is to abide by the rules, not crossing boundary, while Gustakh is an interdisciplinary disruption, taking scholarship and visual culture critically to do some dismantling, for the living subjectivities of the queers in the global south to rise.
How you can help
While the conference has no registration fee, I cannot afford to travel to the UK and present it.
I’m currently in my third year at Habib University, dependent entirely on financial aid and generous donors who have paid for my admission and payable fee to get here. While it’s great to receive a better education than I can ever afford, my financial status does not allow me to travel and pursue opportunities of presenting my work.
Gustakh’s selection for Queer Asia Conference 2018 at SOAS, University of London is beyond my wildest imagination. The book is the manifestation of my ‘failed’ body as I’ve always been treated as, and the love I’ve always been told to hide.
I would be extremely grateful to you, if you could fund this journey.
Expenses
Round-trip airfare: $1000*
A̶c̶c̶o̶m̶m̶o̶d̶a̶t̶i̶o̶n̶:̶ ̶$̶1̶0̶0̶0̶** Found a host!
S̶t̶a̶n̶d̶a̶r̶d̶ ̶U̶K̶ ̶V̶i̶s̶a̶ ̶a̶p̶p̶l̶i̶c̶a̶t̶i̶o̶n̶:̶ ̶$̶1̶2̶5̶ Raised!
Food: $250
H̶e̶a̶l̶t̶h̶ ̶i̶n̶s̶u̶r̶a̶n̶c̶e̶:̶ ̶$̶1̶0̶ Raised!
Travel: $100
Total expense: $1,350
* The flight and accommodation costs are estimated to adjust the changes in exchange rate, flight and Airbnb cost over time.
** The accommodation cost could be crossed out if someone is willing to host me.

story:
Thank You For 30 Years of Support
WE'RE 30!
By supporting The Inn, you make sure children with untreatable diseases have a “place like home” and the best chance for hope. Thank you for being “INN it” and for making childhood and new treatments possible!

OUR MISSION

Mission
The mission of Ocean Partnership for Children (OPC) is to enhance the well-being of youth and their families through natural and community supports.
Vision
Ocean Partnership for Children (OPC) envisions a totally accessible, individualized, family friendly system of care for youth and their families – one that offers the highest quality supports with unconditional care and sustainable success.

What to Expect

Once a child has been referred by PerformCare to Ocean Partnership for Children (OPC), Ocean County’s Care Management Organization (CMO), a Care Manager will make arrangements to meet with the family. During this meeting, the early stages of a plan will develop which will take into account the family’s strengths, values, culture and preferences.

The Child and Family Team & the Care Manager

This team will consist of the child’s Caregiver, the Care Manager, formal service providers such as therapists and in-community providers, and natural or informal supports. A Child and Family Team (CFT) will change and evolve over time and as the needs of the child and family change.

Community Resources

Using the creativity and input from the Child and Family Team, informal community supports and services will be identified for the family. Ocean Partnership has a staff dedicated to seeking out both traditional and non-traditional resources to help a family become more strongly connected to their community and move toward independence.

story:
Who We Are:

We are five students from the University of Tennessee in Knoxville working to give back to the community through our project Vols for Kids. Vols for Kids works specifically to help the non-profit organization CASA of the Tennessee Heartland. We chose this organization because we feel as though non-profits helping abused and neglected children are sometimes over-looked.

CASA of the Tennessee Heartland (CASATNH) is a 501(c)(3) non-profit founded in 1988. Through volunteers, the organization provides a voice for abused and neglected children in the community. The volunteers within the organzation help children that have been brought into the court system through no fault of their own. CASATNH is a volunteer based organization, and with over one hundred volunteers. They served over three hundred children in 2017. 

 

What We Need:

CASA of the Tennessee Heartland is a volunteered based organization. These volunteers are used to advocate for abused and neglected children in the court system. Advocating for a child means a number of things, some of these include, being there for a child during court, taking a child to an athletic event, or even just buying a child a meal. 

To help with the cost of recruiting and training volunteers, we have a goal of raising $1,100 which would help with the recruitment and training of two new volunteers. Each volunteer takes weeks of training before they are allowed to be placed with a child.

Currently CASA does not have enough volunteers to be placed with every child that needs one. To take some of the financial burden of the organization we have decided to help with this fundraiser to provide the funds to recruit and train two volunteers. 

 

How this Helps:

By providing advocates to children in the court system, this means that a child does not go through the court system by themselves. Children in this situation are in the court system due to abuse by their parents. A CASA volunteer is there to help a child and to make sure the child has a voice within the court system. 

Research shows that children with a CASA volunteer do not get "forgotten" in the foster care system, they receive the necessary services, medications, and are less likely to return to the court system. 

One volunteer can advocate for up to seven children at a time, with the recruitment and training of two new volunteers up to fourteen children do not have to face the court system by themselves. Two new volunteers effects the lives of countless children and as a result their lives are changed forever.

Perks:

Donations of all amounts will help us reach our goal of $1100, and to show our gratitude we have a wide range of perks starting at $10. Options include a social media shoutout, t-shirts, and two free tickets to the next upcoming event, as well as a number of other gifts to express our gratitude.  

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

CASA of the Tennessee Heartland relies heavily on volunteers. If you can't donate money, you can still help the organization by donating your time to become a volunteer by helping advocate for a child. 

More information on how you can help is found on CASA of the Tennessee Heartland website or on their Facebook.

story:
Syrian Refugees: The human story

I have been developing the idea for this project since I was in Syria last year to photo-document that terrible conflict as well as spending time in Syrian refugee camps in Lebanon and Jordan. What impressed me the most was the warmth of the people despite all the terrible hardship they are suffering.

Millions of Syrians are now refugees in Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan and they have very little international support. Because of the circumstances they have to find ways of supporting themselves and their families. They are doing this by trying to find work but there also are quite a few who have started small businesses. Syrians are extremely resourceful, they have to be. This project is about telling the stories of these people as they find ways to rebuild their lives in a foreign country. I have kept many of my contacts with Syrians in Jordan. The plan is to follow up on them as well as meet new Syrians to see how their lives have changed in the last year. The objective is to show that although they are refugees they are no different to you and me, they desire security, a home, education and a job. Refugees are often portrayed in the media as pathetic creatures living in the dirt, I want to show their humanity as they work to rebuild their lives.

The project's ultimate goal is to create a book which tells the individual stories of those I will meet, interview and photograph as they go about rebuilding their lives. There will also be exhibitions in Europe and the USA as a continuation of the book and exhibitions I have already produced from my time in Syria last year.

I will also donate 20% of the profit from sales of the book and any photographic works to buy medicines for Syrian refugees. Many cannot afford the medicines they need, particularly for the children so this project will also be of direct benefit to those who need it.


The impact your help will have

The biggest impact your help will have in enabling this project is to give a voice to those who have lost and suffered so much. This project is very much about showing the humanity of ordinary Syrians who are desperate to live in peace and raise their families. We are living at a critical point in human history. Never before has the world seen so many refugees, nearly half the Syrian population has been displaced. This project is about showing we care for our fellow human beings, wherever they are. Together, with your help, I want to bring a different narrative, one that shows the humanity of ordinary Syrians and that with the right help they can rebuild their lives.

Not only am I looking for contributions to fund the project fund but also for publicists who believe in a humanitarian cause and would be willing to help publicize the book and exhibitions for maximum impact. Even if you can not contribute directly, if you feel strongly about what is happening to your fellow human beings, then please spread the word about this project.


Budget

This is based on my budget last year when I went to Syria and the subsequent printing,  production and exhibition costs.

50 large photographic prints, approx 75x50cm on Dibond and laminated @ $200 each = $10,000

Book preparation, layout and initial print run cost $6700

Exhibition expenses for 3 shows in Switzerland, UK and the USA including shipping, insurance, picture hangings and travel. Switzerland approx $2000, UK & USA approx $3350 each. Total $8700

Return Flight to Amman, Jordan approx $1340

Hotel accommodation and food for 3 weeks in Jordan approx $2680

Fixer, driver, translator approx $1000

Indiegogo & PayPal fees $3100

Perk costs $4000

Grand Total $37,520. All costs are in US Dollars.


About Russell Chapman

I'm a freelance photographer and writer who is well versed in the issues of the Middle East. Last year I went to Syria, spending a month to see what is happening on the ground. I wanted to understand the reality of the situation and how it is affecting the Syrian people. After, I spent time in Lebanon and Jordan, visiting refugee camps and talking to the people. I have to say, as a result of my experience of the warmth I encountered despite all the suffering they are going through that I now feel very close to them.

My work in Syria is well recognized. I have been invited to speak and show my work at international conferences at Franklin University in Switzerland, Oxford University in England and the Conference of Forced Migration in Washington DC. My curator is Professor of Art History, Johanna Fassl of Franklin University, Switzerland.

I have done interviews for various international media, my last being for World Refugee Day on June 20th with China Youth Daily, one of the largest newspapers in China

I'm also a fine art photographer and work with the AcquestArte gallery in Ascona, Switzerland to show my art.

Check out the gallery page for this project to see a slide show of some of my photography work in Syria last year.

Please contact me if you have any questions. For more information about me and my work check out: www.russellchapman.wordpress.com

My press release can be seen at:

http://www.releasewire.com/press-releases/photographer-seeks-funding-to-document-how-syrian-refugees-in-jordan-are-rebuilding-their-lives-539236.htm

http://www.ssuchronicle.com/2014/08/19/photographer-seeks-funding-to-document-how-syrian-refugees-in-jordan-are-rebuilding-their-lives/

http://www.digitaljournal.com/pr/2129342

http://world.einnews.com/article__detail/219173192?lcode=80BoKNkjCIaN4yVXx2pgSw%3D%3D

story:
AYWD AND THE CAUSE

Action for Youth and Women Development (AYWD) Uganda is committed to shining a light on the plight of women in rural Uganda who've been widowed with children. While for developed countries, substantial statistical information exists on the ages and numbers of widows, the data available on the subject of widowhood for developing countries are extremely limited. Following the death of a male head of household, it is common for relatives, community members, authority figures and other opportunists to plunder the property (including the home and its surrounding gardens) that belonged to the deceased or to the couple jointly.

Land security is essential to livelihood security for most Ugandans, as over 85% of those who live in rural areas depend on agriculture as the major contributor to their livelihoods.  When widows become victims of property grabbing, they lose not only their homes and personal possessions, but their sources of food and income. As a result, they may become homeless, malnourished, driven further into poverty and vulnerable to further exploitation. In developed countries, widowhood is experienced primarily by elderly women, while in developing countries it also affects younger women, many of whom are still rearing children. In some regions, girls become widows before reaching adulthood.

LEGAL & SOCIAL REALITIES

While the Ugandan Penal Code and other statutes do not include a specific offense called “property grabbing,” the act of stealing a widow’s land violates numerous criminal statutes. Although many property grabbing perpetrators attempt to hide behind customary practices of refusing women and children the right to own property, the Constitution and laws of Uganda supersede such traditions, guaranteeing the equality of land and inheritance rights between men and women as well as the equal protection of the civil and criminal law. Unfortunately, property grabbing against women remains entrenched in the sociocultural and gender norms of Uganda, and the Ugandan public justice system has not effectively delivered on the aspirations of protection and security promised by the law of Uganda.

SOLUTIONS

AWYD aims to provide capacity building through legal advocacy on property issues, business trainings, technical support and micro-loans to struggling widows in Uganda, empowering them to start small businesses and create a better life for their families.

We have just published a book called “The Widows Club”, which features authentic, haunting images and stories of 26 widows and their children. It’s an inspiring piece that offers stories of hope, heartbreak & humanity. The proceeds from the sale of this book will go towards a micro-lending program.  

Today most of the widows and their families survive on one meal a day with very poor diets or even go without food entirely for the day. Worst of all, many needy fatherless children are not getting educated because their mothers or guardians cannot afford to pay to keep them in school. The borrower's priorities for the use of their profits from the business are: better nutrition, healthcare and covering school fees for their children.

FUNDING WIDOWS

Through our participatory approach we will provide interest-free loans to women to start up their own businesses. We will also organize weekly business trainings and will be available to give technical support and business advice to them. Once Loans are paid, we collect and give it to another borrower. Hence revolving funds, moving from one woman to another. Helping needy families afford the basics of life like food, shelter and sending children to school is our goal. By providing a hand-up to struggling widows, we will be helping them achieve their dreams. This fundraising campaign will be a catalyst for change, breaking the viscous cycle of poverty and energizing the community as widows become productive and send their children to school.

We thank you for your heart-felt consideration of this noble cause. Your donation will be immensely appreciated. Please also circulate our campaign to help us reach our goal.

Blessings to you and your family. Respectfully,

Muwayire Henry
Director at AYWD

 

If you're interested in further details on the plight of widows in Uganda and the specifics of our plans to turn lives around, please read our full 20-page funding proposal below.

 

 

 

 

COUNTRY                           :                UGANDA

DISTRICTS                          :               WAKISO

PROJECT TITLE                :               CAPACITY BUILDING AND

                                                            EMPOWERMENT PROJECT OF

                                                                   WIDOWS IN UGANDA

APPLICANT                         :                AYWD UGANDA

AMOUNT REQUESTED    :               CAN $ 59,324

LOCAL CONTRIBUTION  :               CAN $ 9,230

 

 

 

RE:         APPLICATION FOR GRANT SUPPORT OF US$ 37,830 FOR OUR CAPACITY BUILDING AND REVOLVING FUND.

 

We would like to kindly submit in our humble application for consideration of grant support from your esteemed organization.

The grant support would assist us to successfully empower and carry out capacity building / skills training of poor rural Widows i.e. Young mothers from forced and early marriages, victims of domestic violence, HIV/AIDS and women from conflict and post conflict area, enable the organization publish a book on plight of widows for sale in order to fundraise and extend a revolving fund to these poor rural women in the poorest and remote parts of our country to enable them start or improve on their micro-enterprises/income generating micro-projects.

AYWD Uganda is a registered non-profit organization with an innovative approach to empowering women and the youth economically, academically, health wise through pooling resources to help them make ends meet. Believing education to be the single most powerful tool available for reducing poverty in developing young people especially women and young mothers an opportunity to learn the skills needed to earn a living. A focus on agricultural education recognizes the central role of agriculture in the world’s least developed countries as a source of income generation, employment, and food security.

This support would go a long way in the transforming of the economic and social lives of our rural poor women who are often marginalized and lack access to means of production.  We have attached on this letter a copy of our itemized budget for the project.  Our local contribution towards the cost of the project is expected to be CAN $ 9,230.

We shall be very grateful if our project application will be considered.

Yours Sincerely,

Muwayire Henry
Director at AYWD

 

 

CAPACITY BUILDING AND EMPOWERMENT PROJECT FOR RURAL AYWD UGANDA COMMUNITY WOMEN GROUPS IN THE DISTRICT OF WAKISO.

 

Background

In Uganda, children and women experience daily acts of violence at an alarming rate in homes, schools, and communities. Domestic beatings, physical and sexual abuse, and rape or defilement are daily realities that are robbing children and women of their rights and putting their lives at risk. Children in particular suffer abusive power relationships, corporal punish­ment as a method of discipline, and child mar­riage – each a form of violence that is accepted in some corners of Ugandan society. In Uganda, as in other countries, traditions are often used to justify violent acts.

Gender plays an important role in patterns of violence. A lack of options for a girl living in a household means she becomes a burden, a factor contributing to forced early marriage. A woman who is poor and has little options for attaining financial security, or has no access to natural resources, including ownership of land, can be stuck in a life of dependence and at increased risk of gender-based violence.

The most vulnerable of Uganda’s society– youth living on the streets, children who are orphaned, child labourers, or child brides, for instance – are extremely prone to experiencing violence and exploitation. It’s estimated that Uganda has nearly 7.5 million children and youth living in vulnerable situations, and therefore those many millions of Uganda’s future are at risk of having their rights stripped and their lives put at risk.

We at AYWD Uganda have been sensitizing community on issues related to domestic violence, early and forced marriage, human rights, child right and how to smartly leave homes or places where they are subdued in to being domestically abused. The greatest challenge of children and women who are victims of domestic violence is access to shelter and food. Those basic needs have left women to die in silence because they have no financial power to support themselves and their children. A case was captured by AYWD Uganda where a woman hanged herself because of the pain and trauma she was facing, yet she also had no one to run to for help. AYWD Uganda has been sensitizing communities about Domestic violence and its impact on derailing development of children, women and their communities at large.  We have trained many of them in basic skills however, the biggest challenge AYWD Uganda is facing is securing micro-finance services for these women to engage in economic activities for the betterment of their livelihood.

Justification

Women and girls continue to suffer from all forms of Gender Based Violence (GBV), be it physical, economic, emotional and sexual. Gender based violence (GBV) has serious implications for the development of girls and the advancement of women as well as their contribution towards national development. Coupled with these is the weak capacity of institutions to provide redress to victims of GBV especially widows.

Domestic violence is much more rooted from the economic inequalities of women and men and further accelerated by cultural norms. Availing basic skills training and availability of women user friend micro-finance services aimed at improving the livelihood of disadvantaged women groups translated in to have women entrepreneurs having confidence, voice, influence and access to services and opportunities. Women’s access to credit is constrained by unfavorable terms and conditions of credit schemes, need for collateral, high interest rates and small loan sizes.  Therefore, this micro-finance project will focus on providing finance capital for building the capacity of cadres of women Entrepreneurs to establish and sustain viable and competitive enterprises to serve as the backbone of communities, regional and National growth and transformation. Interventions will focus on building skills and knowledge in business and entrepreneurial skills and tap opportunities in key agricultural and non-agricultural sectors and also improve women’s access to employment, credit, financial services and other productive resources.

 

 

INSTITUTIONAL FRAMEWORK

AYWD Uganda will be responsible for the facilitation and monitoring of the project at regional level.  At the community level, the project implementation monitoring and evaluation will be facilitated.

Project Location & Target Group

The Capacity Building and Empowerment Project is located in Central Buganda region of Wakiso District.  The project is to involve 150 poor rural widows who are victims of GBV, HIV, forced and early marriages and those from post conflict areas but residents of Wakiso. The Districts have the largest influx of migrants.

MISSION

An evolving organization that empowers poor communities to be self-reliant through health, education, livelihood and advocacy interventions.

VISION

 Communities where all enjoy equal social and economic transformation for self-reliance.  

Aims and Objectives of the project:

Goal/Aim:

  • To support and economically empower victims of Domestic Violence, GBV, young mothers from forced and early marriages including victims of HIV, FGM and those running from conflicts in their regions and homes focusing on widows. Through providing psycho-social support, basic skills training and financial management skills and finance capital (Revolving Loans) necessary to prepare the 150 members of AYWD Uganda Community Women’s Group for successful micro-entrepreneurship, (agricultural and non-agricultural with a value chain approach) to generate income for themselves and improve their livelihoods and that of their children.  Publication of 500 copies of a book on the testimonies of widows for sale to fundraise for the organization. Documentation of all the processes, findings and learnings.

Objectives:

  • To extend a Revolving Fund to members of the local communities of the economically active poor and marginalized widows between the ages of 18 – 60 years old, so as to empower them engage in income generating agricultural and non-agricultural micro projects and businesses for improving their livelihoods and that of their children.
  • To channel at least 90% of the Revolving Fund to economically active poor widow groups
  • To mobilize and motivate widows who are victims of GBV, HIV, Rape, young mother to engage into productive economic programs / income generating projects by training them in entrepreneurial and business skills.
  • To liberate the widows from economic bondage / dependency, modern slavery, poverty and from marginalization so as to liberate them economically.
  • Sale of 500 books on the plight of widows in Uganda and their fatherless children to fundraise for the organization’s activities.
  • Documentation of the loan portfolio, processes, findings and lessons learned for future lobbying and advocating to change policies and laws on widows.

 

 

Organisation Review and Profile of AYWD Uganda

General Information

(AYWD Uganda) is a non-profit. AYWD Uganda works with rural marginalized women groups and their Children in Uganda in order to alleviate poverty and improve on their livelihoods.

AYWD Uganda has been providing women with  training in basic life skill, HIV/Aids awareness and Positive Living for those living with the virus, for victims of  Domestic Violence we provide  psycho-social support, temporally shelter, basic skills training, sensitizing them on Human Right, children rights, education and Functional Adult Literacy and Credit extension so that the marginalized rural women can create or expand Micro Businesses they can  plan and manage themselves to generate income for their households.  The objective is to liberate these women from dependence on their abuser, and their deprivation of social and economic power.

The Capacity Building and Revolving Fund Program is based on the concept that these women have already received some training which mean that they have the capability and ingenuity to create viable micro-enterprises, agricultural and non-agricultural.  With access to Micro-finance capital and training, they can make their potential a reality.  This AYWD Uganda Revolving Fund Program emphasizes strengthening business skills so that women entrepreneurs are better equipped to sustain and expand their project businesses.  These agricultural and non-agricultural businesses are based on products or services that these know how to make or do, for which there are local markets.

The program is to be implemented by a team of trained Field Officers and Trainers who love their work and their clients to help them develop their business projects.  The Trainers and Field officers facilitate the Credit program including vetting, selecting and training the needy entrepreneurs, approving business plans, monitoring and supervising credit and loan tracking activities and reporting to head office. This will all be documented on the procured laptops to evaluate project progress.

What we have - Our Present Strengths:

  • We have 10 Trainers / Trained Credit / field Officers who carry out training in group formation, group management & group dynamics, savings and Business Management Skills and Pre-loan disbursement education.  The Credit program is headed by the Director assisted by the Treasurer / Credit Manager and Program Coordinator.
  • We have a network of 150 AYWD Uganda Community Group Widows who are beneficiaries of the psycho-social support, shelter, basic skills training and our no to Domestic Violence Campaign who are part of our outreach with 15 beneficiary groups. 
  • We have a geographical outreach/coverage of Wakiso District.

 

 

Needs Present problems and challenges

Inadequate funds to extend revolving loans to needy women groups so as to economically empower them and reduce the risks of them falling in the hands of their abusers because of lack of access to food and other basic needs.  By linking vocational and entrepreneurial education, women not only receive practical instruction on how to produce, but also acquire the business skills needed to earn themselves a living. The production and sale of products that this entails generates income which women are able to use to support their households. This focus on financial sustainability means that every money invested in developing women economic and entrepreneurship capacity at community level will continues to have an impact year after year.

The need to build women’s financial base capacity and create new livelihoods is critical for the peaceful development of any developing country such as Uganda. I hope that our approach inspires your trust to share that vision, and to invest in the future of women as the best approach of changing and improving household incomes and access to basic needs of these community women.

Access to credit, Basic skills Education and training are fundamental tools of empowerment. They provide the poor and disadvantaged women with the means to increase their productivity and income earning power. Education and training can enhance the bargaining power of community women; foster assertiveness and self-confidence; promote greater awareness of legal and social rights; and improve access to and use of economic resources such as jobs, land, credit, and information.  Access to credit, Basic skills Education and training programs are geared towards transformation and structural adjustments of community women economic independence, which increases their control over decisions, resources and structures affecting their lives. In this way, education creates conditions for full and equal participation of people in discussions and decisions, and at the same time empowers all people to act for change.

Lack of proper documentation of the project progress mainly because we lack computers to store the data. Most of the information on beneficiaries, loans, savings and current status of businesses is stored on papers

 

PROJECT DURATION

The project will be implemented over a 2 year period, starting from August 2019 to September 2021.

PERFORMANCE INDICATORS

  • Production and productivity for all targeted crops for widows groups in an Agricultural value chain approach
  • Income of widows from commercialization of their produce and processed products
  • Operating women farmer organizations and cooperatives
  • Number of Widows Entrepreneurs and Enterprises established
  • Widows able to repay their loans
  • Group Members and the Community awareness and understanding of laws and policies protecting the rights of women
  • Women of childbearing age continue to seek and have access to modern family planning method so as to have unwanted pregnancy and have the time to plan for motherhood and raise their manageable families.
  • Establish of CAGVT to monitor, watch for any cases of domestic violence and have it reported to Law enforces, and continue sensitization of their communities on issues related to Domestic Violence.
  • Widows to owner their own land and be able to construct a house 1-2 rooms.
  • Documentation of project progress.
  • Sale of 500 books on the plight of widows in Uganda and their fatherless children to improve organizations performance

 

 

PROJECT COMPONENTS

The project will focus on the following components:

Component 1: Support to Women in Agriculture- value chain approach through:

  • Increased crops, livestock, fisheries/aquaculture and forestry production and management
  • Improved post-harvest handling and value addition for all commodities identified above
  • Strengthening entrepreneurial and financial management skills of women farmers and their associations/cooperatives

Component 2: Entrepreneurship and access to resources for both agricultural and non-agricultural activities through:

  • Development of cadres of Local Women Entrepreneurs and integrated Business Development Services
  • Women’s Access to Financial Services and other productive resources.

Component 3: Strengthening Women’s Rights through:

  • Institutional Strengthening and capacity building
  • Women’s Right Promotion and Protection and access to Sexual and Reproductive Health information and services (SRH).
  • Procurement of 5 laptops for proper documentation of achievements and challenges.
  • Sale of 500 book copies on the plight of widows in Uganda and their fatherless children to improve institutional performance and activities.

AYWD Uganda Scheme / Group Lending Methodology:

This Revolving Fund lending program is based on group lending methodology where needy solidarity groups of 10 women form a borrowing group, but each person has her own business to start or run.  The group members co-guarantee each other’s loans.  There is no collateral, as the poor women lack assets to stake for the loans.  But the group members use peer pressure to ensure loan repayments are done on time and in full.  A built-in saving scheme enables the poor women grasp the essence of savings and to experience a process of financial discipline.  These Savings are handled and managed within and by group members and their group leaders.   The groups are encouraged to open up Bank Accounts with commercial banks of their own choice to keep this savings, before they are transferred to us for custody.  Business counselling and training continues throughout the loan term provided by Group Mentors and Field Officers.

 

 

AYWD Uganda teaches /trains the women groups how to make small savings every week and acquire financial discipline. This savings discipline therefore provides some level of security for the loan program. Therefore, the following conditions obtain under our Credit Extension program:

Ownership:

The beneficiaries identify and plan the businesses themselves and receive advice from AYWD Uganda on the best practices to maximise returns

 

Local Resources:

The Women group member secure their loan, plus those who can access land for agricultural business projects very well and good.

 

Time and Energy:

 

They each work a minimum of 6 hours per day on their project businesses.

 

Self-sufficiency            :

 

They anticipate a profit.

 

Reinvestment

They invest at least 20% of the profit in the enterprise.

Growth

They anticipate a continuing and expanding level of Self-employment.

Domestic consumption

They use at least 30% of the net profits into buying and providing nutritious foods and a balanced diet to their children / families/households.

Accountability             

They report on their businesses and its results

 

The loan beneficiaries submit a business plan which is first appraised at group level before being sent to our organisation for appraisal before receiving the first cycle of loan of US$ 100. They receive the second cycle of loans after submitting a business report, which demonstrates that they have kept records, have established viable enterprises and met program requirements.  The clients continue to save in order to qualify for the next higher loan in the next cycle.  Loan periods are between 4 to 6 months.  A minimal interest rate of 3% per month is charged on the loans to enable the program meet its operational costs and to address the need for sustainability strategy and expand its capital base to serve more new members. 15 organised groups have been identified by our Field Staff and need refresher capacity building /training and later credit extension.  A total of 150 women form the 15 groups for which the grant is sought.

 

 

This Credit Program is to provide low-income women especially victims of Domestic Violence, single mothers living with HIV/AIDS, the opportunity to establish profitable micro-businesses (agricultural and non-agricultural) and increase their incomes, helping them to meet their families’ basic needs.  In addition, they develop organizational, leadership, entrepreneurial, financial management skills, the ability to save and re-invest, and increased confidence in themselves and their future.

Performance of Group Lending Methodology:

AYWD Uganda has been conveniently and efficiently providing these women with psycho-social support, training in basic life skills, financial and business management, agricultural business practices with a value chain approach. The organization is reaching a significant number of the poor marginalized women and victims of Domestic Violence, however there is a high demand for financial capital (micro-credit services for these women).  Hence a need to have more capital resources to step up these women economic empowerment through access to credit.

Use for which the funds are requested:

The grant component we want funding for is primarily for providing Revolving Fund to marginalized Women Groups, refresher training, logistics and publication of 500 copies to be sold and revenue used to increase the organizations capacity to reach more widows. Capacity building and training will be carried out in the following areas:

  1. In Group Management / Group dynamics
  2. In entrepreneurial skills development
  3. In micro-projects investment/Business management
  4. In Book-keeping skills and
  5. Those with agricultural projects (value addition)

Loans will then be extended to these women groups hence economically, socially empowering them and further building their capacity to provide for their families. The grant support will help increase self-respect and esteem among the local women and hence liberating them economically, physically, and socially.

 

 

Beneficiaries of the anticipated grant project funds:

The beneficiaries will be 150 poor rural / needy women in Wakiso District.

Intended benefits to the beneficiaries:

  1. Building capacity in skills such as entrepreneurial/business management skills, leadership skills.
  2. Empowering beneficiaries economically towards self-sufficiency to enable beneficiaries generate enough income for their households.
  3. Social emancipation of rural women (they will learn leadership skills and group organisation and management) to enable them participates fully in the social and economic life of this country.
  4. Acquisition of literacy and functional skills, credit with education will equip functional skills and literacy skills to needy women since this will be incorporated as a training component.  They will be able now to identify, buy or grow and provide nutritious foods for their children to combat malnutrition and marasmus and feed a balanced diet to their households.
  5. They will mobilise savings, build and internalise a culture of savings and develop financial discipline through systematic and spontaneous savings under the credit programme.
  6. Young women with no capital or incomes who would otherwise resort to a life of crime, prostitution would now become economically productive and escape temptations of promiscuity and risking HIV/AIDS as well as surviving fall back in to abusive relationships.
  7. At least by the end of the 2 years each woman should have her own plot of land and a one or two-bedroom house.

Resource Requirements:

  • Funds are required for the Revolving Loan facilitation, training to 150 rural women in 15 groups.
  • Funds for logistical support, such as for training venues, accommodation for facilitators, meals, refreshments, transport, fuel, stationery, typesetting, typing and printing, photocopying, and binding workshop materials.
  • Procurement of 5 laptops for proper documentation of activities, outcomes, outputs of the project and storage of current and previous data
  • Funds to publish 500 books titled the plight of widows in Uganda and their fatherless children to sale to raise revenue for the organizations outreach to other widows.

 

 

In addition to grant support, the following sources will also be considered to sustain the programme.

  • Internal sources such as retained earnings and surplus from the lending program will need to be ploughed back, to increase the loan portfolio / capital base.
  • In addition, external sources of funds such as soft loans and commercial loans will also be used to finance the planned development.
  • Earnings from the sale of 500 books which will increase the number of beneficiaries served and skilled.

Source of our present funds

Our organization has been able to get some funding and or logistical support from the following sources:

  • Local savings from members – locally mobilised savings
  • Board members’ contributions.

Movement towards financial independence

Our staff are already trained in Micro-finance best practices and loan tracking systems.  In addition, government policy which favours decentralization of services and the setting up of village banks, rural credit schemes and micro-finance institutions have greatly favoured our operations.  The passing of the Micro-Financing Bill into a law will greatly favours Micro-Finance operations in the country.

Project self-sustainability

Our micro-credit program is projected to fully reach self-sufficiency by December 2021 in two (2) years’ time.  An increased clientele will mean more interest revenue for the program, which will contribute to a growing revolving fund and a reduced cost per unit of loan lent.  Measures to be taken to reduce long-term dependence on grants and subsidies will include re-capitalizing our loan portfolio by ploughing back interest earned from the loan-lending program. With our growth plan, we are fully set to become self-sustainable by the end of the year 2021 and to attain operational efficiency at the beginning of June 2021.

 

 

A loan loss reserve fund of 5% of the loan portfolio will be set aside to insure any bad debts.  This money will be put on a Fixed Deposit Account at a Commercial Bank to earn us a fixed deposit interest rate of 5% per month.  As a measure to safeguard against bad debts.  Then we plan to take an Insurance Policy and Insurance Program for women group loans with a local Insurance Company.  Careful loan portfolio management and loan tracking will be applied to enhance portfolio quality.  Already 5 staff have been trained in loan tracking and MFI best practices.

Our Revolving Fund program hopes to build a solid and growing fund base with clear business plans, backed by operational capacities that lead to mobilization of commercial funds from depositors and the financial system and eventually to full independence from donor support by the end of the year 2021 by generating its own income and enough to sustain the program.

Our Future plans

  • To expand our Revolving Fund Program to target all other marginalized women who may be in need of the support. We will continue training and sensitization, advocacy for women rights and emancipation train and to have continuous follow up.  Development programs and projects that provide women with employment. 
  • Document all the loan portfolio on the laptops and the success stories of all the beneficiaries. Also, setup a website for international viewing of the project progress.
  • Lobby and source for agricultural inputs and mechanization grants/loans to accelerate commercial farming projects for these women Group and many more.
  • Continue outreach programs to reach more communities.
  • To expand our capacity building / training program to gain more capacity by recruiting more field/ training staff.  Also to acquire more equipment for training, such as video, camera, digital camera, projector.
  • To introduce new products / services such as health insurance scheme (micro-care) for micro-credit clients in conjunction with relevant service providers.
  • To take up insurance scheme for our Revolving Fund Program so as to ensure and maximise all our local repayments to 100%.
  • Sale of more boos titled the plight of widows in Uganda and their fatherless children to public as a fundraising strategy.

 

 

Purpose of the grant being applied for:

(a)       The grant we are applying for will enable AYWD Uganda achieve the following:

Re-train and serve 150 Rural Poor women groups directly with:

  1. Training in basic business / entrepreneurial skills / micro-business management.
  2. Provide and extend to them Revolving Fund to invest in their micro-enterprises.
  • To build our capacity to provide more services to the low-income local women, more efficiently.  To increase numbers of rural community women group beneficiaries who will have access to our much-needed services.
  • Expand our outreach.  We shall be able to expand our geographical coverage to more remote sub-counties in more remote areas where there is greatest need for empowerment of poor rural women – where credit and business skills are much needed.
  • Promoting the grassroots women in the economic and social development of their lives e.g. developing and replicating new models for community investment.
  • Introduce financial products and services to the targeted communities.
  • Acquire enough materials for training and business counselling.
  • Improve the following:
    • Increase our loan capital base / loan revolving fund.
    • Improve service deliver
    • Improve operation efficiency
    • Enhance our monitoring and supervision capabilities.

(b)       The grant will enable the poor rural women beneficiaries achieve the following:

  • Access training from our staff and experienced professional training providers in business skills and business management.
  • Access credit for their micro-business, leading to increased incomes for participating households and better nutrition.
  • Access high quality financial services and products.
  • Get empowered socially and economically.
  • Access functional Literacy Education.
  • Increased self-respect and esteem among rural poor women clients who will strive to succeed and overcomes poverty.
  • Alleviation of poverty from their midst.
  • Will acquire financial discipline and learn how to save and invest.
  • Through such empowerment, the project will enhance local level participation of the grassroots population (women who are victims of Gender Bases Violence) in local policy.

 

 

Training Curriculum & timing

There is an established training curriculum covering 2 weeks’ period for the women groups.   The details of the timing / timetable can be availed upon request.

Work-plan

The actual refresher training of the women could start as soon as grant funds are got.  The training will take a period of 2 weeks to accomplish.  In the meantime, the women trainees will continue to work on the business plans and ideas and advices will be given to them on what is to be added or eliminated basing on the market dynamics. Revolving Fund loan disbursements to the women could start as soon as the training is over as soon as their entrepreneur projects qualify for funding.

Monitoring supervision

Business counselling, business mentoring and loan tracking by Field Officers will continue throughout the loan period.  Report making will be a continuous process.  And this will be done daily and weekly summaries submitted to the Credit Manager by the Field Officers.  The Credit Manager will make both weekly and monthly summaries to the Director.

Evaluation / Report Making

Monitoring will be a continuous process assessing whether the project is progressing towards the achievement of specific objectives. Implementation of plans will be the subject of monitoring and the results of monitoring will be fed-back into the re-planning process for subsequent periods. The purpose of monitoring will be to compare the progress of activities and their outputs with the plans as developed in the projects. A final internal evaluation will be carried out in order to draw lessons for future. The results coming up from the evaluation will be integral part of the narrative final report. The evaluation will be carried on during the final stage of the project. Annual reports including household surveys will be done to determine the impact of the program on the rural women and their households.  Both performance and operational indicators will be used to measure progress and achievements of the program.  A report to the donors will be submitted after 13 calendar months after receipt of the grant funds.  The following indicators will also be addressed in the evaluation:

 

 

Management of funds

The organization applies a strong recognized Financial Management Principle to manage their financial resources. A strong system has been instituted to safeguard utilization of the organizations’ resources and ensure appropriate Internal Controls over the financial function which includes Management Information Systems; Custody of assets, Segregation of duties, Approval and Authorization of transactions at different levels of responsibility. With a strong inbuilt Monitoring, Evaluation and Reporting procedures the system facilitates provisions of timely regular reports for all the stakeholders.

The financial and accounting policies and procedures are based on International Accounting Standards and maintain a distinct disclosure of Capital, Recurrent, Partners’ Designated and Other Funds. Annual external audits are undertaken by an internationally recognized firm of Certified Public Accountants, who issue certified reports to development partners, donors and members.

 

 

PROPOSED BUDGET FOR THE EXPECTED GRANT FUNDS
RE-TRAINING COMPONENT (2WEEKS NON-RESIDENTIAL TRAINING WORKSHOP)
FOR 15 GROUPS AND EXTENSION OF REVOLVING FUND
story_txt:
AYWD AND THE CAUSEAction for Youth and Women Development (AYWD) Uganda is committed to shining a light on the plight of women in rural Uganda who've been widowed with children. While for developed countries, substantial statistical information exists on the ages and numbers of widows, the data available on the subject of widowhood for developing countries are extremely limited. Following the death of a male head of household, it is common for relatives, community members, authority figures and other opportunists to plunder the property (including the home and its surrounding gardens) that belonged to the deceased or to the couple jointly.Land security is essential to livelihood security for most Ugandans, as over 85% of those who live in rural areas depend on agriculture as the major contributor to their livelihoods.  When widows become victims of property grabbing, they lose not only their homes and personal possessions, but their sources of food and income. As a result, they may become homeless, malnourished, driven further into poverty and vulnerable to further exploitation. In developed countries, widowhood is experienced primarily by elderly women, while in developing countries it also affects younger women, many of whom are still rearing children. In some regions, girls become widows before reaching adulthood.LEGAL & SOCIAL REALITIESWhile the Ugandan Penal Code and other statutes do not include a specific offense called “property grabbing,” the act of stealing a widow’s land violates numerous criminal statutes. Although many property grabbing perpetrators attempt to hide behind customary practices of refusing women and children the right to own property, the Constitution and laws of Uganda supersede such traditions, guaranteeing the equality of land and inheritance rights between men and women as well as the equal protection of the civil and criminal law. Unfortunately, property grabbing against women remains entrenched in the sociocultural and gender norms of Uganda, and the Ugandan public justice system has not effectively delivered on the aspirations of protection and security promised by the law of Uganda.SOLUTIONSAWYD aims to provide capacity building through legal advocacy on property issues, business trainings, technical support and micro-loans to struggling widows in Uganda, empowering them to start small businesses and create a better life for their families.We have just published a book called “The Widows Club”, which features authentic, haunting images and stories of 26 widows and their children. It’s an inspiring piece that offers stories of hope, heartbreak & humanity. The proceeds from the sale of this book will go towards a micro-lending program.  Today most of the widows and their families survive on one meal a day with very poor diets or even go without food entirely for the day. Worst of all, many needy fatherless children are not getting educated because their mothers or guardians cannot afford to pay to keep them in school. The borrower's priorities for the use of their profits from the business are: better nutrition, healthcare and covering school fees for their children.FUNDING WIDOWSThrough our participatory approach we will provide interest-free loans to women to start up their own businesses. We will also organize weekly business trainings and will be available to give technical support and business advice to them. Once Loans are paid, we collect and give it to another borrower. Hence revolving funds, moving from one woman to another. Helping needy families afford the basics of life like food, shelter and sending children to school is our goal. By providing a hand-up to struggling widows, we will be helping them achieve their dreams. This fundraising campaign will be a catalyst for change, breaking the viscous cycle of poverty and energizing the community as widows become productive and send their children to school.We thank you for your heart-felt consideration of this noble cause. Your donation will be immensely appreciated. Please also circulate our campaign to help us reach our goal.Blessings to you and your family. Respectfully,Muwayire HenryDirector at AYWD

 
If you're interested in further details on the plight of widows in Uganda and the specifics of our plans to turn lives around, please read our full 20-page funding proposal below.
    
COUNTRY                           :                UGANDA
DISTRICTS                          :               WAKISO
PROJECT TITLE                :               CAPACITY BUILDING AND
                                                            EMPOWERMENT PROJECT OF
                                                                   WIDOWS IN UGANDA
APPLICANT                         :                AYWD UGANDA
