LOCAL CONTRIBUTION  :               CAN $ 9,230
 
 
 
RE:         APPLICATION FOR GRANT SUPPORT OF US$ 37,830 FOR OUR CAPACITY BUILDING AND REVOLVING FUND.
 
We would like to kindly submit in our humble application for consideration of grant support from your esteemed organization.
The grant support would assist us to successfully empower and carry out capacity building / skills training of poor rural Widows i.e. Young mothers from forced and early marriages, victims of domestic violence, HIV/AIDS and women from conflict and post conflict area, enable the organization publish a book on plight of widows for sale in order to fundraise and extend a revolving fund to these poor rural women in the poorest and remote parts of our country to enable them start or improve on their micro-enterprises/income generating micro-projects.
AYWD Uganda is a registered non-profit organization with an innovative approach to empowering women and the youth economically, academically, health wise through pooling resources to help them make ends meet. Believing education to be the single most powerful tool available for reducing poverty in developing young people especially women and young mothers an opportunity to learn the skills needed to earn a living. A focus on agricultural education recognizes the central role of agriculture in the world’s least developed countries as a source of income generation, employment, and food security.
This support would go a long way in the transforming of the economic and social lives of our rural poor women who are often marginalized and lack access to means of production.  We have attached on this letter a copy of our itemized budget for the project.  Our local contribution towards the cost of the project is expected to be CAN $ 9,230.
We shall be very grateful if our project application will be considered.
Yours Sincerely,
Muwayire HenryDirector at AYWD
 

 
CAPACITY BUILDING AND EMPOWERMENT PROJECT FOR RURAL AYWD UGANDA COMMUNITY WOMEN GROUPS IN THE DISTRICT OF WAKISO.
 
Background
In Uganda, children and women experience daily acts of violence at an alarming rate in homes, schools, and communities. Domestic beatings, physical and sexual abuse, and rape or defilement are daily realities that are robbing children and women of their rights and putting their lives at risk. Children in particular suffer abusive power relationships, corporal punish­ment as a method of discipline, and child mar­riage – each a form of violence that is accepted in some corners of Ugandan society. In Uganda, as in other countries, traditions are often used to justify violent acts.
Gender plays an important role in patterns of violence. A lack of options for a girl living in a household means she becomes a burden, a factor contributing to forced early marriage. A woman who is poor and has little options for attaining financial security, or has no access to natural resources, including ownership of land, can be stuck in a life of dependence and at increased risk of gender-based violence.
The most vulnerable of Uganda’s society– youth living on the streets, children who are orphaned, child labourers, or child brides, for instance – are extremely prone to experiencing violence and exploitation. It’s estimated that Uganda has nearly 7.5 million children and youth living in vulnerable situations, and therefore those many millions of Uganda’s future are at risk of having their rights stripped and their lives put at risk.
We at AYWD Uganda have been sensitizing community on issues related to domestic violence, early and forced marriage, human rights, child right and how to smartly leave homes or places where they are subdued in to being domestically abused. The greatest challenge of children and women who are victims of domestic violence is access to shelter and food. Those basic needs have left women to die in silence because they have no financial power to support themselves and their children. A case was captured by AYWD Uganda where a woman hanged herself because of the pain and trauma she was facing, yet she also had no one to run to for help. AYWD Uganda has been sensitizing communities about Domestic violence and its impact on derailing development of children, women and their communities at large.  We have trained many of them in basic skills however, the biggest challenge AYWD Uganda is facing is securing micro-finance services for these women to engage in economic activities for the betterment of their livelihood.
Justification
Women and girls continue to suffer from all forms of Gender Based Violence (GBV), be it physical, economic, emotional and sexual. Gender based violence (GBV) has serious implications for the development of girls and the advancement of women as well as their contribution towards national development. Coupled with these is the weak capacity of institutions to provide redress to victims of GBV especially widows.
Domestic violence is much more rooted from the economic inequalities of women and men and further accelerated by cultural norms. Availing basic skills training and availability of women user friend micro-finance services aimed at improving the livelihood of disadvantaged women groups translated in to have women entrepreneurs having confidence, voice, influence and access to services and opportunities. Women’s access to credit is constrained by unfavorable terms and conditions of credit schemes, need for collateral, high interest rates and small loan sizes.  Therefore, this micro-finance project will focus on providing finance capital for building the capacity of cadres of women Entrepreneurs to establish and sustain viable and competitive enterprises to serve as the backbone of communities, regional and National growth and transformation. Interventions will focus on building skills and knowledge in business and entrepreneurial skills and tap opportunities in key agricultural and non-agricultural sectors and also improve women’s access to employment, credit, financial services and other productive resources.
 

 
INSTITUTIONAL FRAMEWORK
AYWD Uganda will be responsible for the facilitation and monitoring of the project at regional level.  At the community level, the project implementation monitoring and evaluation will be facilitated.
Project Location & Target Group
The Capacity Building and Empowerment Project is located in Central Buganda region of Wakiso District.  The project is to involve 150 poor rural widows who are victims of GBV, HIV, forced and early marriages and those from post conflict areas but residents of Wakiso. The Districts have the largest influx of migrants.
MISSION
An evolving organization that empowers poor communities to be self-reliant through health, education, livelihood and advocacy interventions.
VISION
 Communities where all enjoy equal social and economic transformation for self-reliance.   
Aims and Objectives of the project:
Goal/Aim:
To support and economically empower victims of Domestic Violence, GBV, young mothers from forced and early marriages including victims of HIV, FGM and those running from conflicts in their regions and homes focusing on widows. Through providing psycho-social support, basic skills training and financial management skills and finance capital (Revolving Loans) necessary to prepare the 150 members of AYWD Uganda Community Women’s Group for successful micro-entrepreneurship, (agricultural and non-agricultural with a value chain approach) to generate income for themselves and improve their livelihoods and that of their children.  Publication of 500 copies of a book on the testimonies of widows for sale to fundraise for the organization. Documentation of all the processes, findings and learnings.
Objectives:

To extend a Revolving Fund to members of the local communities of the economically active poor and marginalized widows between the ages of 18 – 60 years old, so as to empower them engage in income generating agricultural and non-agricultural micro projects and businesses for improving their livelihoods and that of their children.
To channel at least 90% of the Revolving Fund to economically active poor widow groups
To mobilize and motivate widows who are victims of GBV, HIV, Rape, young mother to engage into productive economic programs / income generating projects by training them in entrepreneurial and business skills.
To liberate the widows from economic bondage / dependency, modern slavery, poverty and from marginalization so as to liberate them economically.
Sale of 500 books on the plight of widows in Uganda and their fatherless children to fundraise for the organization’s activities.
Documentation of the loan portfolio, processes, findings and lessons learned for future lobbying and advocating to change policies and laws on widows.

 

 
Organisation Review and Profile of AYWD Uganda
General Information
(AYWD Uganda) is a non-profit. AYWD Uganda works with rural marginalized women groups and their Children in Uganda in order to alleviate poverty and improve on their livelihoods.
AYWD Uganda has been providing women with  training in basic life skill, HIV/Aids awareness and Positive Living for those living with the virus, for victims of  Domestic Violence we provide  psycho-social support, temporally shelter, basic skills training, sensitizing them on Human Right, children rights, education and Functional Adult Literacy and Credit extension so that the marginalized rural women can create or expand Micro Businesses they can  plan and manage themselves to generate income for their households.  The objective is to liberate these women from dependence on their abuser, and their deprivation of social and economic power.
The Capacity Building and Revolving Fund Program is based on the concept that these women have already received some training which mean that they have the capability and ingenuity to create viable micro-enterprises, agricultural and non-agricultural.  With access to Micro-finance capital and training, they can make their potential a reality.  This AYWD Uganda Revolving Fund Program emphasizes strengthening business skills so that women entrepreneurs are better equipped to sustain and expand their project businesses.  These agricultural and non-agricultural businesses are based on products or services that these know how to make or do, for which there are local markets.
The program is to be implemented by a team of trained Field Officers and Trainers who love their work and their clients to help them develop their business projects.  The Trainers and Field officers facilitate the Credit program including vetting, selecting and training the needy entrepreneurs, approving business plans, monitoring and supervising credit and loan tracking activities and reporting to head office. This will all be documented on the procured laptops to evaluate project progress.
What we have - Our Present Strengths:

We have 10 Trainers / Trained Credit / field Officers who carry out training in group formation, group management & group dynamics, savings and Business Management Skills and Pre-loan disbursement education.  The Credit program is headed by the Director assisted by the Treasurer / Credit Manager and Program Coordinator.
We have a network of 150 AYWD Uganda Community Group Widows who are beneficiaries of the psycho-social support, shelter, basic skills training and our no to Domestic Violence Campaign who are part of our outreach with 15 beneficiary groups. 
We have a geographical outreach/coverage of Wakiso District.

 

 
Needs Present problems and challenges
Inadequate funds to extend revolving loans to needy women groups so as to economically empower them and reduce the risks of them falling in the hands of their abusers because of lack of access to food and other basic needs.  By linking vocational and entrepreneurial education, women not only receive practical instruction on how to produce, but also acquire the business skills needed to earn themselves a living. The production and sale of products that this entails generates income which women are able to use to support their households. This focus on financial sustainability means that every money invested in developing women economic and entrepreneurship capacity at community level will continues to have an impact year after year.
The need to build women’s financial base capacity and create new livelihoods is critical for the peaceful development of any developing country such as Uganda. I hope that our approach inspires your trust to share that vision, and to invest in the future of women as the best approach of changing and improving household incomes and access to basic needs of these community women.
Access to credit, Basic skills Education and training are fundamental tools of empowerment. They provide the poor and disadvantaged women with the means to increase their productivity and income earning power. Education and training can enhance the bargaining power of community women; foster assertiveness and self-confidence; promote greater awareness of legal and social rights; and improve access to and use of economic resources such as jobs, land, credit, and information.  Access to credit, Basic skills Education and training programs are geared towards transformation and structural adjustments of community women economic independence, which increases their control over decisions, resources and structures affecting their lives. In this way, education creates conditions for full and equal participation of people in discussions and decisions, and at the same time empowers all people to act for change.
Lack of proper documentation of the project progress mainly because we lack computers to store the data. Most of the information on beneficiaries, loans, savings and current status of businesses is stored on papers
 
PROJECT DURATION
The project will be implemented over a 2 year period, starting from August 2019 to September 2021.
PERFORMANCE INDICATORS

Production and productivity for all targeted crops for widows groups in an Agricultural value chain approach
Income of widows from commercialization of their produce and processed products
Operating women farmer organizations and cooperatives
Number of Widows Entrepreneurs and Enterprises established
Widows able to repay their loans
Group Members and the Community awareness and understanding of laws and policies protecting the rights of women
Women of childbearing age continue to seek and have access to modern family planning method so as to have unwanted pregnancy and have the time to plan for motherhood and raise their manageable families.
Establish of CAGVT to monitor, watch for any cases of domestic violence and have it reported to Law enforces, and continue sensitization of their communities on issues related to Domestic Violence.
Widows to owner their own land and be able to construct a house 1-2 rooms.
Documentation of project progress.
Sale of 500 books on the plight of widows in Uganda and their fatherless children to improve organizations performance

 

 
PROJECT COMPONENTS 
The project will focus on the following components:
Component 1: Support to Women in Agriculture- value chain approach through:

Increased crops, livestock, fisheries/aquaculture and forestry production and management
Improved post-harvest handling and value addition for all commodities identified above
Strengthening entrepreneurial and financial management skills of women farmers and their associations/cooperatives

Component 2: Entrepreneurship and access to resources for both agricultural and non-agricultural activities through:

Development of cadres of Local Women Entrepreneurs and integrated Business Development Services
Women’s Access to Financial Services and other productive resources.

Component 3: Strengthening Women’s Rights through:

Institutional Strengthening and capacity building
Women’s Right Promotion and Protection and access to Sexual and Reproductive Health information and services (SRH).
Procurement of 5 laptops for proper documentation of achievements and challenges.
Sale of 500 book copies on the plight of widows in Uganda and their fatherless children to improve institutional performance and activities.

AYWD Uganda Scheme / Group Lending Methodology:
This Revolving Fund lending program is based on group lending methodology where needy solidarity groups of 10 women form a borrowing group, but each person has her own business to start or run.  The group members co-guarantee each other’s loans.  There is no collateral, as the poor women lack assets to stake for the loans.  But the group members use peer pressure to ensure loan repayments are done on time and in full.  A built-in saving scheme enables the poor women grasp the essence of savings and to experience a process of financial discipline.  These Savings are handled and managed within and by group members and their group leaders.   The groups are encouraged to open up Bank Accounts with commercial banks of their own choice to keep this savings, before they are transferred to us for custody.  Business counselling and training continues throughout the loan term provided by Group Mentors and Field Officers.
 

 
AYWD Uganda teaches /trains the women groups how to make small savings every week and acquire financial discipline. This savings discipline therefore provides some level of security for the loan program. Therefore, the following conditions obtain under our Credit Extension program:


Ownership:

The beneficiaries identify and plan the businesses themselves and receive advice from AYWD Uganda on the best practices to maximise returns
 



Local Resources:

The Women group member secure their loan, plus those who can access land for agricultural business projects very well and good.
 




Time and Energy:
 


They each work a minimum of 6 hours per day on their project businesses.
 




Self-sufficiency            :
 


They anticipate a profit.
 



Reinvestment 
They invest at least 20% of the profit in the enterprise.


Growth
They anticipate a continuing and expanding level of Self-employment.


Domestic consumption
They use at least 30% of the net profits into buying and providing nutritious foods and a balanced diet to their children / families/households.


Accountability              
They report on their businesses and its results


 
The loan beneficiaries submit a business plan which is first appraised at group level before being sent to our organisation for appraisal before receiving the first cycle of loan of US$ 100. They receive the second cycle of loans after submitting a business report, which demonstrates that they have kept records, have established viable enterprises and met program requirements.  The clients continue to save in order to qualify for the next higher loan in the next cycle.  Loan periods are between 4 to 6 months.  A minimal interest rate of 3% per month is charged on the loans to enable the program meet its operational costs and to address the need for sustainability strategy and expand its capital base to serve more new members. 15 organised groups have been identified by our Field Staff and need refresher capacity building /training and later credit extension.  A total of 150 women form the 15 groups for which the grant is sought.
 

 
This Credit Program is to provide low-income women especially victims of Domestic Violence, single mothers living with HIV/AIDS, the opportunity to establish profitable micro-businesses (agricultural and non-agricultural) and increase their incomes, helping them to meet their families’ basic needs.  In addition, they develop organizational, leadership, entrepreneurial, financial management skills, the ability to save and re-invest, and increased confidence in themselves and their future.
Performance of Group Lending Methodology:
AYWD Uganda has been conveniently and efficiently providing these women with psycho-social support, training in basic life skills, financial and business management, agricultural business practices with a value chain approach. The organization is reaching a significant number of the poor marginalized women and victims of Domestic Violence, however there is a high demand for financial capital (micro-credit services for these women).  Hence a need to have more capital resources to step up these women economic empowerment through access to credit.
Use for which the funds are requested:
The grant component we want funding for is primarily for providing Revolving Fund to marginalized Women Groups, refresher training, logistics and publication of 500 copies to be sold and revenue used to increase the organizations capacity to reach more widows. Capacity building and training will be carried out in the following areas:

In Group Management / Group dynamics
In entrepreneurial skills development
In micro-projects investment/Business management
In Book-keeping skills and
Those with agricultural projects (value addition)

Loans will then be extended to these women groups hence economically, socially empowering them and further building their capacity to provide for their families. The grant support will help increase self-respect and esteem among the local women and hence liberating them economically, physically, and socially.
 

 
Beneficiaries of the anticipated grant project funds:
The beneficiaries will be 150 poor rural / needy women in Wakiso District.
Intended benefits to the beneficiaries:

Building capacity in skills such as entrepreneurial/business management skills, leadership skills.
Empowering beneficiaries economically towards self-sufficiency to enable beneficiaries generate enough income for their households.
Social emancipation of rural women (they will learn leadership skills and group organisation and management) to enable them participates fully in the social and economic life of this country.
Acquisition of literacy and functional skills, credit with education will equip functional skills and literacy skills to needy women since this will be incorporated as a training component.  They will be able now to identify, buy or grow and provide nutritious foods for their children to combat malnutrition and marasmus and feed a balanced diet to their households.
They will mobilise savings, build and internalise a culture of savings and develop financial discipline through systematic and spontaneous savings under the credit programme.
Young women with no capital or incomes who would otherwise resort to a life of crime, prostitution would now become economically productive and escape temptations of promiscuity and risking HIV/AIDS as well as surviving fall back in to abusive relationships.
At least by the end of the 2 years each woman should have her own plot of land and a one or two-bedroom house.

Resource Requirements:

Funds are required for the Revolving Loan facilitation, training to 150 rural women in 15 groups.
Funds for logistical support, such as for training venues, accommodation for facilitators, meals, refreshments, transport, fuel, stationery, typesetting, typing and printing, photocopying, and binding workshop materials.
Procurement of 5 laptops for proper documentation of activities, outcomes, outputs of the project and storage of current and previous data
Funds to publish 500 books titled the plight of widows in Uganda and their fatherless children to sale to raise revenue for the organizations outreach to other widows.

 

 
In addition to grant support, the following sources will also be considered to sustain the programme.

Internal sources such as retained earnings and surplus from the lending program will need to be ploughed back, to increase the loan portfolio / capital base.
In addition, external sources of funds such as soft loans and commercial loans will also be used to finance the planned development.
Earnings from the sale of 500 books which will increase the number of beneficiaries served and skilled.

Source of our present funds
Our organization has been able to get some funding and or logistical support from the following sources:

Local savings from members – locally mobilised savings
Board members’ contributions.

Movement towards financial independence
Our staff are already trained in Micro-finance best practices and loan tracking systems.  In addition, government policy which favours decentralization of services and the setting up of village banks, rural credit schemes and micro-finance institutions have greatly favoured our operations.  The passing of the Micro-Financing Bill into a law will greatly favours Micro-Finance operations in the country.
Project self-sustainability
Our micro-credit program is projected to fully reach self-sufficiency by December 2021 in two (2) years’ time.  An increased clientele will mean more interest revenue for the program, which will contribute to a growing revolving fund and a reduced cost per unit of loan lent.  Measures to be taken to reduce long-term dependence on grants and subsidies will include re-capitalizing our loan portfolio by ploughing back interest earned from the loan-lending program. With our growth plan, we are fully set to become self-sustainable by the end of the year 2021 and to attain operational efficiency at the beginning of June 2021.
 

 
A loan loss reserve fund of 5% of the loan portfolio will be set aside to insure any bad debts.  This money will be put on a Fixed Deposit Account at a Commercial Bank to earn us a fixed deposit interest rate of 5% per month.  As a measure to safeguard against bad debts.  Then we plan to take an Insurance Policy and Insurance Program for women group loans with a local Insurance Company.  Careful loan portfolio management and loan tracking will be applied to enhance portfolio quality.  Already 5 staff have been trained in loan tracking and MFI best practices.
Our Revolving Fund program hopes to build a solid and growing fund base with clear business plans, backed by operational capacities that lead to mobilization of commercial funds from depositors and the financial system and eventually to full independence from donor support by the end of the year 2021 by generating its own income and enough to sustain the program.
Our Future plans

To expand our Revolving Fund Program to target all other marginalized women who may be in need of the support. We will continue training and sensitization, advocacy for women rights and emancipation train and to have continuous follow up.  Development programs and projects that provide women with employment. 
Document all the loan portfolio on the laptops and the success stories of all the beneficiaries. Also, setup a website for international viewing of the project progress.
Lobby and source for agricultural inputs and mechanization grants/loans to accelerate commercial farming projects for these women Group and many more.
Continue outreach programs to reach more communities.
To expand our capacity building / training program to gain more capacity by recruiting more field/ training staff.  Also to acquire more equipment for training, such as video, camera, digital camera, projector.
To introduce new products / services such as health insurance scheme (micro-care) for micro-credit clients in conjunction with relevant service providers.
To take up insurance scheme for our Revolving Fund Program so as to ensure and maximise all our local repayments to 100%.
Sale of more boos titled the plight of widows in Uganda and their fatherless children to public as a fundraising strategy.

 

 
Purpose of the grant being applied for:
(a)       The grant we are applying for will enable AYWD Uganda achieve the following:
Re-train and serve 150 Rural Poor women groups directly with:

Training in basic business / entrepreneurial skills / micro-business management.
Provide and extend to them Revolving Fund to invest in their micro-enterprises.


To build our capacity to provide more services to the low-income local women, more efficiently.  To increase numbers of rural community women group beneficiaries who will have access to our much-needed services.
Expand our outreach.  We shall be able to expand our geographical coverage to more remote sub-counties in more remote areas where there is greatest need for empowerment of poor rural women – where credit and business skills are much needed.
Promoting the grassroots women in the economic and social development of their lives e.g. developing and replicating new models for community investment.
Introduce financial products and services to the targeted communities.
Acquire enough materials for training and business counselling.
Improve the following:
Increase our loan capital base / loan revolving fund.
Improve service deliver
Improve operation efficiency
Enhance our monitoring and supervision capabilities.



(b)       The grant will enable the poor rural women beneficiaries achieve the following:

Access training from our staff and experienced professional training providers in business skills and business management.
Access credit for their micro-business, leading to increased incomes for participating households and better nutrition.
Access high quality financial services and products.
Get empowered socially and economically.
Access functional Literacy Education.
Increased self-respect and esteem among rural poor women clients who will strive to succeed and overcomes poverty.
Alleviation of poverty from their midst.
Will acquire financial discipline and learn how to save and invest.
Through such empowerment, the project will enhance local level participation of the grassroots population (women who are victims of Gender Bases Violence) in local policy.

 

 
Training Curriculum & timing
There is an established training curriculum covering 2 weeks’ period for the women groups.   The details of the timing / timetable can be availed upon request.
Work-plan
The actual refresher training of the women could start as soon as grant funds are got.  The training will take a period of 2 weeks to accomplish.  In the meantime, the women trainees will continue to work on the business plans and ideas and advices will be given to them on what is to be added or eliminated basing on the market dynamics. Revolving Fund loan disbursements to the women could start as soon as the training is over as soon as their entrepreneur projects qualify for funding.
Monitoring supervision
Business counselling, business mentoring and loan tracking by Field Officers will continue throughout the loan period.  Report making will be a continuous process.  And this will be done daily and weekly summaries submitted to the Credit Manager by the Field Officers.  The Credit Manager will make both weekly and monthly summaries to the Director.
Evaluation / Report Making
Monitoring will be a continuous process assessing whether the project is progressing towards the achievement of specific objectives. Implementation of plans will be the subject of monitoring and the results of monitoring will be fed-back into the re-planning process for subsequent periods. The purpose of monitoring will be to compare the progress of activities and their outputs with the plans as developed in the projects. A final internal evaluation will be carried out in order to draw lessons for future. The results coming up from the evaluation will be integral part of the narrative final report. The evaluation will be carried on during the final stage of the project. Annual reports including household surveys will be done to determine the impact of the program on the rural women and their households.  Both performance and operational indicators will be used to measure progress and achievements of the program.  A report to the donors will be submitted after 13 calendar months after receipt of the grant funds.  The following indicators will also be addressed in the evaluation:
 

 
Management of funds
The organization applies a strong recognized Financial Management Principle to manage their financial resources. A strong system has been instituted to safeguard utilization of the organizations’ resources and ensure appropriate Internal Controls over the financial function which includes Management Information Systems; Custody of assets, Segregation of duties, Approval and Authorization of transactions at different levels of responsibility. With a strong inbuilt Monitoring, Evaluation and Reporting procedures the system facilitates provisions of timely regular reports for all the stakeholders.
The financial and accounting policies and procedures are based on International Accounting Standards and maintain a distinct disclosure of Capital, Recurrent, Partners’ Designated and Other Funds. Annual external audits are undertaken by an internationally recognized firm of Certified Public Accountants, who issue certified reports to development partners, donors and members.
  PROPOSED BUDGET FOR THE EXPECTED GRANT FUNDSRE-TRAINING COMPONENT (2WEEKS NON-RESIDENTIAL TRAINING WORKSHOP)FOR 15 GROUPS AND EXTENSION OF REVOLVING FUND

story:
Women’s Rights Must Exist NOW!

   These are difficult times for everyone saddled with empathy, courage and, for this campaign…female anatomy. The Decent and Intelligent must fight against willful ignorance and entitlement. When I did this campaign the first time (2014) things didn’t seem as bad as they are now. Then there was definitely a shroud hiding the realities of this country — it was yanked off by the 2016 election.

   Vaginas, uteri and guns have one major thing in common: blood. Gun makers, gun dealers and gun lovers have a better comprehension of firearms than pastors, politicians and doctors have of vaginas and uteri. Yet, somehow, there is more regulation of women’s magical and mysterious anatomy than automatic weapons. This country is tipping backwards. The arms that wave and try to maintain balance — connected to people with empathy and courage — are flailing against an onslaught of willful ignorance and greed.

   Please help me get my image out to a wider audience and help Planned Parenthood. Contributions, of any size, and SHARING with everyone will help immensely. Think of this as an empowerment t-shirt, pin, sticker or poster. Wear the them to rallies. Wear them to work, parties and weddings! Help fuel the power of women's rights and help our country mature and move in the right direction.

   As with my previous campaign, all proceeds will be donated to Planned Parenthood, and the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence. The balance will go into having more shirts, pins stickers and posters produced.

Thank you!

When I did this campaign the first time (2014) things didn’t seem as bad as they are now. Then there was definitely a shroud hiding the realities of this country — it was yanked off by the 2016 election.
   Vaginas, uteri and guns have one major thing in common: blood. Gun makers, gun dealers and gun lovers have a better comprehension of firearms than pastors, politicians and doctors have of vaginas and uteri. Yet, somehow, there is more regulation of women’s magical and mysterious anatomy than automatic weapons. This country is tipping backwards. The arms that wave and try to maintain balance — connected to people with empathy and courage — are flailing against an onslaught of willful ignorance and greed.
   Please help me get my image out to a wider audience and help Planned Parenthood. Contributions, of any size, and SHARING with everyone will help immensely. Think of this as an empowerment t-shirt, pin, sticker or poster. Wear the them to rallies. Wear them to work, parties and weddings! Help fuel the power of women's rights and help our country mature and move in the right direction.
   As with my previous campaign, all proceeds will be donated to Planned Parenthood, and the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence. The balance will go into having more shirts, pins stickers and posters produced.
Thank you!

story:
Ach, so ist das?!

Unterstütze die LGBTI* Community und trage zu Akzeptanz und Vielfalt in unserer Gesellschaft bei :) 


Hallo! ich bin Martina Schradi und engagiere mich seit 2013 in dem Projekt "Ach, so ist das?!". 

Unter diesem Motto sammle ich Geschichten über Lebensweise und Erfahrungen von LGBTI* – Lesben, Schwulen, Bis, Trans und Intersexuellen – und zeichne daraus biografische Comicreportagen.

 

Mit den Comics möchte ich alle Interessierten einladen, sich in der Welt der LGBTI* umzusehen, ihre Lebensweise, Erfahrungen und alles, was sie bewegt, sichtbar und begreifbar machen – ganz jenseits von gängigen Klischees! 

Mit den Comics möchte ich möglichst viele Menschen erreichen und für das Thema interessieren. Daher habe ich bereits ein Buch veröffentlicht, ein zweites folgt in Kürze. Außerdem gab es eine Posterausstellung, die schon in vielen Ländern in Europa und in Nordamerika mit großem Erfolg gezeigt wurde. Mit den Postern, die zu einem günstigen Preis zu kaufen ist, können Vereine, Schulen, Universitäten, Einrichtungen aller Art eine tolle Ausstellung machen und auf diese Weise viele Menschen erreichen.

 

Ich engagiere mich außerdem mit Lesungen und Vorträgen zu meinen Comics um noch mehr Menschen für das Thema zu interessieren. Bis zu 200 Veranstaltungen gab es in den letzten Jahren zu "Ach, so ist das?!".

Das Projekt ist auch schon mehrfach ausgezeichnet worden. Und ein Team von Pädagog_innen hat ein passendes Programm entwickelt, um mit den Comics Akzeptanz-Workshops an Schulen durchzuführen. Das haben wir inzwischen mehrfach mit großem Erfolg durchgeführt.

Ein Riesenteil in dem Projekt wird übrigens ehrenamtlich gestemmt.

Unter www.achsoistdas.com kannst du dir ein Bild vom Projekt machen. 

Leider sind nun die erste Ausstellung und alle Printmaterialien zum Projekt weg und es sind auch viele neue Geschichten hinzugekommen. Wir bekommen wöchentlich Anfragen wann es endlich eine neue Auflage der Ausstellung gibt.

Hier könnt ihr mich unterstützen: Mit einer kleinen oder größeren Spende ermöglicht ihr eine Neuauflage der Posterausstellung. 

Mit deiner Spende unterstützt du die LGBTI* Community und trägst zu Akzeptanz und Vielfalt in unserer Gesellschaft bei :) 

Wie sieht das konkret aus?

Es soll eine neue Auflage der ersten Ausstellung geben, mit 12 Best-Of-Geschichten zu den Themen:

  • Coming Out in der Familie, in der Schule und am Arbeitsplatz
  • Umgang mit Geschlechterrollen und geschlechtstypischen Erwartungen
  • Freundschaft und Liebe bei LGBTI*
  • Fragen der Identität
  • Diskriminierungserfahrungen, z.B. am Arbeitsplatz
  • Infoposter zu den wichtigsten Begriffen

Außerdem soll es eine neue Ausstellung geben mit ca. 16 neuen Postern mit den Themen:

  • Unterstützung, Empowerment
  • Bisexuelle Identität
  • Non-Binarität und 3. Geschlecht
  • Displaced Persons, Migration und Flucht von LGBTI*
  • Infoposter zu den wichtigsten Begriffen

Mit den Spenden wollen wir diese Poster und ggf. andere Materialien finanzieren.

Ohne die finanzielle Unterstützung können wir leider keine neue Posterausstellung zur Verfügung stellen.

Diese Aktion wird unterstützt vom Trotzdem! e.V.

Ein Riesenteil in dem Projekt wird übrigens ehrenamtlich gestemmt.
Unter www.achsoistdas.com kannst du dir ein Bild vom Projekt machen. 
Leider sind nun die erste Ausstellung und alle Printmaterialien zum Projekt weg und es sind auch viele neue Geschichten hinzugekommen. Wir bekommen wöchentlich Anfragen wann es endlich eine neue Auflage der Ausstellung gibt.
Hier könnt ihr mich unterstützen: Mit einer kleinen oder größeren Spende ermöglicht ihr eine Neuauflage der Posterausstellung. 

Mit deiner Spende unterstützt du die LGBTI* Community und trägst zu Akzeptanz und Vielfalt in unserer Gesellschaft bei :) 

Wie sieht das konkret aus?
Es soll eine neue Auflage der ersten Ausstellung geben, mit 12 Best-Of-Geschichten zu den Themen:

Coming Out in der Familie, in der Schule und am Arbeitsplatz
Umgang mit Geschlechterrollen und geschlechtstypischen Erwartungen
Freundschaft und Liebe bei LGBTI*
Fragen der Identität
Diskriminierungserfahrungen, z.B. am Arbeitsplatz
Infoposter zu den wichtigsten Begriffen


Außerdem soll es eine neue Ausstellung geben mit ca. 16 neuen Postern mit den Themen:

Unterstützung, Empowerment
Bisexuelle Identität
Non-Binarität und 3. Geschlecht
Displaced Persons, Migration und Flucht von LGBTI*
Infoposter zu den wichtigsten Begriffen

Mit den Spenden wollen wir diese Poster und ggf. andere Materialien finanzieren.
Ohne die finanzielle Unterstützung können wir leider keine neue Posterausstellung zur Verfügung stellen.

Diese Aktion wird unterstützt vom Trotzdem! e.V.

story:
Short Summary about Us

We are students at the University of Tennessee, Knoxville. The passion that this organization embodies is prevalent in its efforts and we are excited to join in its community in any way we can. This organization is close to home and it is easy to advocate for something as amazing as Bridge Refugee Services. We are working to raise awareness and support for refugees entering the United States as the numbers allowed to enter are dwindling by the years. By volunteering as well as donating to our campaign you are allowing refugees a peaceful transition and also a better life in your community.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is simple: to support refugees where support is lacking. Our monetary goal is to raise $1,000 in order to support refugees and provide them with basic necessities. The funds provided by you, our donors, will be given to Bridge Refugee Services and they will utilize them in ways that will put refugees back on their feet. Bridge offers refugees sewing programs and garden projects to help integrate them into their new lives. Your donations will allow these projects to be possible along with helping single, new, and pregnant mothers have access to things like diapers, clothes, and baby food. By donating, you can choose to receive perks such as t-shirts, stickers, baseball caps, mugs, etc. The specific perk given to you will depend on the value of your donation. 

 

The Impact

The number of refugees admitted to the United States was once 100,000 which changed to 30,000 and is now at an all time low of 18,000. With this number in mind, as well as a recent executive order that permits state and local government to decide at the local level how many refugees to admit, it is important to understand the drastic changes made to the United States and how these changes affect those outside of our country. The US refugee resettlement program is threatened by these small numbers and needs our support to bring awareness to refugees and their needs. Donations, volunteerism and local support will help compensate for the lack of national support given to them. Refugees fear persecution and safety during their transition period, so with the support of the local Knoxville community, their fears could be limited and they can focus on basic needs like food, shelter and education. 

 

Other ways you can help

There are a couple different ways to help Bridge Refugee Services. Bridge’s website, https://www.bridgerefugees.org/ has two main tabs that you can use to donate or volunteer. These tabs are the “monetarily” and “in kind” tabs. Under the “monetarily” tab there are several options of your choosing to which you want to donate towards. Under the “in kind” tab the donations go towards refugee’s homes. Donations for their homes helps refugees by creating a warm and welcoming home that fosters safety.

 Also, there is an opportunity for students at UT to join an advocacy group called RAISE Refugees. RAISE Refugees is for students who are interested in supporting, taking action, and being apart of something bigger than themselves in the hopes to welcome and encourage refugees. For more information about joining this awesome advocacy group contact Katy Powell at kpowell@utk.edu or Carmella Cole at volunteerknox@bridgerefugees.org to see if this is something you would like to be part of.

story:
Millions of children around the world lack access to basic necessities, such as food, clean water, sanitation, medicine, shelter, education, books, fun, family, ...

 

Summary

Education is the primary source for children to keep their life in safe way. This project provides education material to poor children upto elementary section. Basic education material required for their studies without any interruption is our goal.

 

Still in India poor people are unable to provide quality of education to their children. Un-education or illeteracy may cause lack of knowledge and unemployment.

Solution

This project will help to provide basic needs to children go for school without any interruption. We provide books, school uniforms, note books, travel charges and health care. Hence every one able to go for school.

Long-Term Impact

This project will help to develop children may get education. In future there is no question of unemployment, illiteracy. Poor people can study their children without any financial struggles.

The project is to improve the educational status of poor children. The specific objectives of the project are to initiate the community to advocate for support and 

Education is the primary source for children to keep their life in safe way. This project provides education material to poor children upto elementary section

story:
Short Summary

It’s the first project of its kind in our region. Words can't describe how important it is to me, us, society, region, country. We pray for the achievement of the goal. The success of this endeavor relies on YOU. Your involvement will help us start something necessary, special, and important.

What We Need & What You Get

For less than that starbucks latte, you could support the independent, community-focused journalism this region badly needs. Together, we will continue to grow this revolution. By crowdfunding here on indiegogo, we are able to stay completely independent and 100% accountable to the people who matter most – our advocates. There is urgency behind this mission. Crowdfunding allows us to move forward quickly and without financial blessing or permission from any higher institutions.

The Impact

The free flow of information and ideas lies at the heart of the very notion of democracy and is crucial to effective respect for human rights. Democracy demands that individuals are able to participate effectively in decision making and assess the performance of their government. With the help of  ATAMAN, we are trying to correct the imbalance. If the global community does not fight the imbalances that exist at a local level in developing countries, this epidemic can sweep the whole world! The greatest challenge isn’t one pertaining to capacity, but to fostering a shift from a culture of secrecy to one of transparency. Therefore, the promotion of a change of mindsets in the public sector and of widespread public awareness and information demand is critical.

Risks & Challenges

The success of project Ataman now relies heavily on community support, so the biggest obstacle to full realization of this project would be underfunding. We expected to launch the project on our own, but miscalculated the budget a bit. Perhaps it is even better. The search for funding brought us here, and the support of the international community make it legitimate and recognizable! When we produce the Ataman, we put everything on the map, since we will not have the opportunity to return to our former life. Your help will give us extra time, helps to do things that we would not dare.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate to our cause, donate some time to sharing this important campaign to your family, friends and associates on your Facebook || Twitter || Linked-In || Instagram || Snapchat pages!

MAKE SOME NOISE!!!

 

P.S.:If you know of someone else willing to offer any help please let them know by sending them a link to this site.

story:
It's Time For a CHANGE!!

With the most recent senseless murders of innocent black lives such as Floyd Brown, Breonna Taylor, and Trayvon Martin - to name a few - the Black Community is fed up and have finally had enough. In an effort to show America that we want true change and equality for the Black man and the Black Lives Matter movement under the P.I.F.F. chapter, we are initiating the Petition for Change and the March of the 144,000 on June 30, 2020.

In response to the barbaric murders of Black people, brutal police killings against innocent Black lives, unfair criminal laws and unjust jail sentences designed against the Black Community, and a poor representation of equality and equal justice for the Black Community in 2020 and dating back to slavery times, the "Voice of the Underground" -- P.I.F.F. Magazine -- and several large organizations from all over the globe are uniting together on a common goal to establish the "Petition for Change" and the new P.I.F.F. Nation - where all lives are considered truly equal.

Under the laws and principles of the new-found P.I.F.F. Nation, the P.I.F.F. family seeks and vows to protect all of its members under provision of shelter, food, transportation, and needed resources. To establish the beginning foundation of our new community for Black Lives Matter under the P.I.F.F. chapter and the equal business platforms and industry accesses, we are asking all members to make a founding donation and BLM pledge for at least $1. For those truly seeking change in America, we are hoping to reach at least 1,000 members and raise at least $30,000 USD to initiate the beginning phases of our movement! Read below to see more about our cause.

 

Positive Vibes Only

Sponsored by some of the biggest companies in the entertainment industry such as Wu-Tang, Def Jam Records, Select Oil, Powerhouse 106 FM, and Legal Mobb Entertainment to name a few, P.I.F.F. Magazine is the magazine that offers a promotional platform for the underground, independent, and aspiring talent. Highlighting all entertainers looking for a place in which to have their voices heard, we are the bridge between the streets and the entertainment industry that represents positive change for a better tomorrow.

We represent all models, music artists, comedians, poets, photographers, athletes, fashion designers, dancers, and entrepreneurs of the entertainment industry and are offering a one-time last-minute involvement in the movement before we go fully public and become a household name. Whether you're small-time, big-time, or just somebody who's interested in learning more about the entertainment industry and its business, we're supporting your dream and burning away all the nonsense while giving you some strong  

P.ositive I.nfluence F.or the F.uture 

 

Our Movement

We are creating a worldwide movement that will represent the urban community and offering the following exclusives:

OPERATION BLACKOUT

I. PETITION FOR CHANGE (6/16/2020 - 6/30/2020):

During our "Petition for Change" phase, we will seek to raise up funds to purchase a building where we can offer shelter, protection, and services to members of P.I.F.F. Nation. Using a list of the names of all the people who have vowed to make a donation and a BLM pledge to the United States government for change and equality, we shall present the demands of the P.I.F.F. Nation from our members to the U.S. government as we seek justice and answers in a peaceful and humble way.

The vision is that we shall utilize these funds to purchase a building in Phoenix, Arizona and begin our community which will be a resource center for all those seeking equality. Donation requests and the Plan of Action are as follows:

Donation Requests

  •  $1 - Black Lives Matter pledge & name on Banner (30,000 people)
    • Make your pledge of your definition of change you'd like to see for P.I.F.F. Nation and have your name listed on our Banner for Change and as a founding member
  •  $7 - Black Lives Matter Issue print copy [Exclusive Collector's Item] (1,000 people)
    • Receive a Collector's Item of P.I.F.F. Magazine's first official print issue, the "Black Lives Matter" Issue
  •  $15 - P.I.F.F. Magazine Affiliate Royalty Program (777 people)
    • Get a position in P.I.F.F. Magazine to receive exclusive promotions and royalties and affiliate commissions off of our company sales and promotions
  •  $188 - Residential Safety Plan Program (150 people)
    • Help us to raise the funds to secure our first building and you will reserve a permanent lifetime position in our shelter placement program at the same time as repair and improve your credit.

Plan of Action

  • Raise a minimum of 1,000 contributing members who will make a pledge for change to the U.S. government to see a difference in human rights laws for the urban community 
  • Raise a minimum of $30,000 USD in which we will use to purchase our first resource center building in Phoenix, Arizona and further our cause and movement on a global scale as we establish our verified Chapters within each State of the U.S. government
  • Establish a nation of equality for all P.I.F.F. members where nobody in our community is left out and where all those seeking change can find it in our community of leaders
  • Re-establish Royalty and place a King & Queen ahead of each chapter of P.I.F.F. Nation
  • On June 30, 2020, we will present our list of contributing members' names on a list known as the "Petition for Change". We will present this list to the American government in seek of our humble, peaceful, and modest demands for change and equality and will ask for the necessary laws to be changed in our favor for the establishment of equality, protection, shelter, transportation, food, and any other needed resources under the P.I.F.F. Nation.
  • We will use the funds in which our community has raised to purchase a resource building within Phoenix, Arizona and will offer all contributors an equal share in this resource center.
  • We will order 1,000 copies of our first national print campaign of Collector's Item issues of our "Black Lives Matter" Issue and will deliver all purchased copies to our members.
  • We will position 777 members into our Affiliate Royalty Program for only $15 (normally priced at $150) to receive royalties off our movement for the longevity of the marathon.
  • We will position 150 people into our Credit Repair Program as well as offer them a lifelong position in our assisted living program.
  • We will donate 5% of our complete raised funds total to Nipsey Hussle's TMC movement.
  • We donate 5% of our complete raised funds total to the Black Lives Matter movement.
  • We will begin the March of the 144,000 on June 30, 2020 as we prepare to lead a peaceful protest to Washington, D.C.

 

II. MARCH OF THE 144K (6/30/2020 - 7/4/2020):

During our "March of the 144,000", we will call for all top leaders around America to begin the March of the 144,000 to the White House in Washington, D.C. to seek the answers and the changes that the Black Community seeks in addition to the urban community.

This march shall begin launchings from multiple locations spreadout across America, so that there is no central starting point in which the government can stop or shut us down. Only those who are truly a part of the movement will know where these march launches will initiate, but to everyone who is a part of the fight for change, they will know where to go at the time it shall begin.

We shall march 144,000+ strong to the capitol of America, also known as the White House, and we shall address the Trump administration on the equality we are searching for. When we arrive in D.C., we shall lift up the voices of the underground to address America's sins against the urban community and we shall seek valid changes as we present our "Petition for Change" to the U.S. government in hopes of positive change for tomorrow's generation.

 

III. BLACKOUT DAY 2020 (7/1/2020 - 7/7/2020):

During our March of the 144,000 and throughout the Blackout Day 2020, we as a community seek to not spend a single $1 to the American government. Co-signed by several large figures - including Atlanta rapper T.I. - Blackout Day will officially commence on July 7, 2020 in memory of our fallen Black soldiers including Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Floyd Brown, and several other Black lives that were terminated and exterminated as a flame that bothers those who fear its bright shine and illumination.

During our first annual Blackout Day in which we seek positive change and reform nationwide for the Black Lives Matter movement, we are extending our holiday to last for a week long from July 1, 2020 - July 7, 2020. The purpose of this week-long extension is to show that we mean serious business and we are NOT PLAYING with the Trump administration on our demands for change.

Supported by Nike, we vow to not spend a single dollar in the American economy from 7:00 AM EST on July 1, 2020 - 11:00 PM EST on July 7, 2020 to prove how important the Black dollar is within America and the affect we can make as a united community. During this timeframe, P.I.F.F. Magazine will have all business operations shut down.

We will not transfer any financial transactions during this week either through CashApp, PayPal, streets, etc, for we know that any transaction made in America has a middle man that leads back to the U.S. economy and therefore, goes against our fight for change; especially on July 4, also known as "Independence Day" for we know that nobody within the Black Community has ever been independent or treated as such in this country, nor do we believe that this is our holiday; therefore, we will not celebrate it.

 

The Impact

For far too long, the Black Community has stood silent and humble awaiting the hands of justice to treat us equally as if a poor child holding their breath on Christmas Eve in hopes of receiving a gift that they know their providers have no means of offering but on the vessel of broken promises and empty vows.

Abducted, kidnapped, traded, and bought from out of the depths of our true Royalty in the motherland of Africa and transformed into niggers and slaves inside an America designed against the Black man, we have gone for generation after generation of government supremacy and mass murder of extermination of the Black man, father, leader, and seed carrier as they continue to strive to use our Black women to create some type of super race that eliminates the Black father and true King.

Through this initiative, we seek to make a change in this broken cycle.

We are committed to changing at least 1,000 lives over the next 12 months and are committed to the Black Lives Matter movement and rebuilding at least 25 urban communities. Your contribution will make this change possible.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Share our updates on all your social media
  • Offer assistance to any P.I.F.F. member

This march shall begin launchings from multiple locations spreadout across America, so that there is no central starting point in which the government can stop or shut us down. Only those who are truly a part of the movement will know where these march launches will initiate, but to everyone who is a part of the fight for change, they will know where to go at the time it shall begin.
We shall march 144,000+ strong to the capitol of America, also known as the White House, and we shall address the Trump administration on the equality we are searching for. When we arrive in D.C., we shall lift up the voices of the underground to address America's sins against the urban community and we shall seek valid changes as we present our "Petition for Change" to the U.S. government in hopes of positive change for tomorrow's generation.
 
III. BLACKOUT DAY 2020 (7/1/2020 - 7/7/2020):
During our March of the 144,000 and throughout the Blackout Day 2020, we as a community seek to not spend a single $1 to the American government. Co-signed by several large figures - including Atlanta rapper T.I. - Blackout Day will officially commence on July 7, 2020 in memory of our fallen Black soldiers including Trayvon Martin, Breonna Taylor, Floyd Brown, and several other Black lives that were terminated and exterminated as a flame that bothers those who fear its bright shine and illumination.
During our first annual Blackout Day in which we seek positive change and reform nationwide for the Black Lives Matter movement, we are extending our holiday to last for a week long from July 1, 2020 - July 7, 2020. The purpose of this week-long extension is to show that we mean serious business and we are NOT PLAYING with the Trump administration on our demands for change.
Supported by Nike, we vow to not spend a single dollar in the American economy from 7:00 AM EST on July 1, 2020 - 11:00 PM EST on July 7, 2020 to prove how important the Black dollar is within America and the affect we can make as a united community. During this timeframe, P.I.F.F. Magazine will have all business operations shut down.
We will not transfer any financial transactions during this week either through CashApp, PayPal, streets, etc, for we know that any transaction made in America has a middle man that leads back to the U.S. economy and therefore, goes against our fight for change; especially on July 4, also known as "Independence Day" for we know that nobody within the Black Community has ever been independent or treated as such in this country, nor do we believe that this is our holiday; therefore, we will not celebrate it.
 
The Impact
For far too long, the Black Community has stood silent and humble awaiting the hands of justice to treat us equally as if a poor child holding their breath on Christmas Eve in hopes of receiving a gift that they know their providers have no means of offering but on the vessel of broken promises and empty vows.
Abducted, kidnapped, traded, and bought from out of the depths of our true Royalty in the motherland of Africa and transformed into niggers and slaves inside an America designed against the Black man, we have gone for generation after generation of government supremacy and mass murder of extermination of the Black man, father, leader, and seed carrier as they continue to strive to use our Black women to create some type of super race that eliminates the Black father and true King.
Through this initiative, we seek to make a change in this broken cycle.
We are committed to changing at least 1,000 lives over the next 12 months and are committed to the Black Lives Matter movement and rebuilding at least 25 urban communities. Your contribution will make this change possible.
Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Share our updates on all your social media
Offer assistance to any P.I.F.F. member

story:
Education is the route out of poverty for manychildren. It gives them a chance to gain the knowledge and skills needed to improve their lives. ...Children miss out on school because their families need them to earn money. But by sacrificing their education, they become trapped in a cycle of poverty.

Funds :

We need around 4000 USD so we can send 100 poor children to school and bear out their basic needs.

story:
WE ARE "LOVE SHOES" PROGRAM FROM VIETNAM!

Vietnam is a developing country & there are many children in difficult living situation:

  • 1,3 million disable children.
  • Around 180,000 orphan all over Vietnam.

Many of those children can not have any shoes to wear & have to face many risks from damage feet, cold, even bring to dead.

They also can not have the confident vs other children with new shoes.

WHO WE ARE & OUR MISSION

We are the husband & wife with 2 kids located in Hanoi city, capital of Vietnam. After 8 years working in volunteer program for VFCD Org (Volunteer for community development), we establish a small business (named Dr.ChaiR) to get profit to sponsor for our "LOVE SHOES" program. We manufacture & sell the toilet spool brand name Dr.ChaiR & each product we sell, we purchase a new shoe for a child with disable or difficulty situation. (about our business, you can see on www.drchair.net - but only in Vietnamese language).

In our "Love shoes" trips, we saw many terrible living situation of children, they are too poor to have shoes to wear & have to play in a garbage with many risk of damage for legs, feet. We also saw the lack of confident when a poor child wore a old damage shoes come to school.

Or a disable girl with Cerebral Palsy disease ran without shoes & get hurt by chip because of her parent don't have enough money to buy her shoes.

Therefore, we run this campaign to raise fund for 10.000 new shoes for difficulty children in Vietnam.

Ethnic children without shoes

A boy & a girl live in a garbage, happy with new shoes

A meal in a social centre, many children eat in a big bowl with only rice & vegetable

 

A smile of Cerebral Palsy child when get a new shoes

HOW WE WILL DO IT!

Raise fund up to 50,000 USD (5 USD for a pair of new shoes)

Collect information about social centre for difficulty children (align with other NGO's data)

Manufacture shoes with neutral design (for both boy & girl) with quantity 10,000 packs. (Now, we only using Dr.ChaiR money, cannot produce large quantity, only buy from shoe dealers, not match with our expectation design (neutral)

Send shoes to needed children by ourself or co-operate with other organization (need to verify needed children)

Report to you.

HOW YOU CAN HELP!

Sponsor Us 

Share a link to this crowdfunder with your networks

Like us on Facebook

story:
Project Summary

PositiveNets was developed by a team of entrepreneurs and was recently winner of TechStars Weekend Long Island sponsored by Google. 

PositiveNets aims to be an online platform that allows you to interact and donate to homeless individuals through the convenience of your mobile device.  In an ever increasing cashless world homeless people are finding themselves left out the cold when it comes to cash donations; it is estimated that only one of three New Yorkers carry physical cash on them.

With PositiveNets homeless people can register for a digital code with their local social worker.  The homeless individual can then share their digital code with the general public which directs users to their online profile.   Users can then read the individuals profile page, background story and established goals and donate to them if they choose.

Donors can feel confident that money is going towards established goals to their path out of poverty, as their digital donation is loaded on to a pre-paid debit card that is only valid at approved vendors.  Donors can also feel confident that 100% of their contribution go towards the homeless individuals road to financial stability.

By contributing to the PositiveNets project you can now digitally help the millions of homeless people around the world reconnect with their local community over a digital platform while also helping raise them out of poverty through words of encouragement and digital donations toward their established goals.

What We Need & What You Get

PositiveNets is seeking to raise $5,000 in initial funding to build the first version of the application.

By donating to PostiveNets your name will be included in our founding donors page on our website's platform. 

The Impact

Many times isolation is the main contributor of mental illness in the homeless population; PositiveNets aims to change this by allowing the general public to safely and securely interact with the homeless population over our digital platform.

By donating to PositiveNets you can feel proud that you were involved in helping millions of homeless people in your local community and around the world out of poverty and on the road to financial stability.   

Risks & Challenges

PositiveNets will need to build relationships with local homeless shelters and social workers to help identify and create digital profiles for the homeless population.  

We plan to work with volunteers to help assist us on-board homeless shelters and social workers in identifying and creating profiles on the platform.  We have secured a strategic partnership with ID Pass to provide an identity through a decentralized identification solution to the most vulnerable populations.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute?  That doesn't mean you can't help.

  • Please help spread the PositiveNets campaign with everyone you know and share our campaign on all of your social media platforms.
  • Sign up to volunteer with PositiveNets and help us on-board social workers who assist validating homeless individual's identities.

story:
Short Summary

Director Jackie Kong & The InSanity Tour has a hand full of VIP tickets to the Los Angeles Final Screening of the Blood Diner National Tour Finale celebrating the re-release of the Lionsgate BluRay to  benefit FEM Directors Unite .

YOU can support our Goal to put the many talented FEM genre and horror directors to work. All contributions will go to developing the horror/genre TV Series entitled "Tempest Territory" with the expressed goal , that all episodes will be directed by FEM Directors.

Legendary director Jackie Kong is spearheading the project's goal  to create the show series, and more opportunities for femaile directors who have proven themselves yet find no jobs. Let's get these talented women to work. 

YOUR VIP Perk SPONSORS the hard work necessary for women to participate in an industry which only has 4% inclusion for Fem Directors. You can be a supporter of Equality for Women, and these amazing new FEM directors. Let's get that number up , after all women are more than 50 % of the population. Have a Blast, while making a difference!

Here's your chance to give more than lip service by leveling the playing field for women,  take action, all while having incredibly InSane time at this Screening Event that pulls out all the stops .

Kong was named Top 6 Legendary Female Directors by Blumhouse.com & has been on the Blood Diner InSanity Tour taking the country by storm in Austin, NYC (Alamo Drafthouses), Miami, Denver,Vancouver, Seattle, Portland, San Francisco to ecstatic fans ...and now wraps the Tour in Los Angeles. See BLOOD DINER on the BIG SCREEN, remastered...it's your last chance to catch the InSanity!!    

 Tour Info at www.facebook.com/findingsheetar

NY Times reporter Fahima Haque asked Jackie if times have changed since she was a pioneer in Horror films decades ago. And her answer is "no" because the opportunites don't exist, even if you prove yourself. Opportunities for inclusion need to be consciously made. Inclusion for women does not just happen on it own, you have to create it, Companies and people must rally support by sponsoring ways to make change happen! When Kong won the 2016 Etheria Fest Inspiration award, she pledged to champion women horror directors, and get others onboard to create opportunity. So she dedicated herself to helping to find sponsors, and developing this platform for change through the development of the series "Tempest Territory". 

Kong, a proven filmmaker with accolades from critics and financial hits for major companies,  says women need more than unfulfilled promises to be included. See Jackie's bio at http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0465034/

Your VIP Ticket will go towards the Development of the show series concept and creating the pilot for the "Tempest Territory" series starting with a screenplay to be written by Award-winning playwright John O'Keefe. O'Keefe, who has won numerous awards including the LA Drama Critics Award and Bessie Award for his acclaimed plays , Shimmer, Don't call me anything but Mother. See his bio on Wikipedia at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_O%27Keefe_(p...

Jackie Kong received the Inspiration Award 2016

Just a couple of Bad-ass FEM Directors with their awards! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't afford hundreds, but still want to champion FEM Directors, Get your ticket at CineFamily, then get  the RIP VIP ticket upgrade only 20 bucks! then get a RIP VIP Upgrade Perk!

"There are two kinds of horror fans out there: those who have seen BLOOD DINER, and those who have not. If you’re in the latter category, this writer pities you, as Jackie Kong’s insane, gory-as-hell horror comedy classic is one that needs to be seen to be believed. And thanks to Lionsgate’s revival..."- Fangoria

All Proceeds from this campaign will go towards developing the series "Tempest Territory" . We will get as far as the funds take us, and hope it catches fire! No guarantees the show will be made, but we will do eveything in our power to make the show a reality, with your help.  Get your VIP Seats now and support the cause!

story:
• Our vision is to continue having a positive impact on society and the lives of the people served in our projects, ensuring a better future for street people, adolescents and their families, fighting against existing inequalities, providing the best service and a social contribution Transparent, with a team ready to help.

 

  • Our mission is to provide excellent care to recipients of social assistance, through an integrated set of actions developed in partnership with the public power.
     

  • Our aim is to promote a better life for street people and adolescents, Protect the environment, Provide support to ensure positive change  people lives served by the projects, Continue to have the acceptance  of  Sorocaba´s citizens.

  • SOS Project ECO - Environmental Education is based on the promotion of environmental education and the training of young people in advanced techniques of cultivation and planting of native species. In this way, the conservation and awareness of the need to protect the environment and biodiversity in the region are valued. This work facilitates the social reintegration of young people, especially those in the process of social exclusion.

    The SOS ECO Project aims to develop environmental actions in the area of its property, located next to its administrative headquarters.

New Hope , be part of the change.

 

In Sorocaba and SOS we are aware that there is still a lot of work to be done so that every day we work to be able to give people who did not have the happiness to have a stable life as well as the lack of more opportunities for personal growth and for Being able to give them a new hope is necessary to obtain more economic resources in order to change more lives, this will be achieved with your support which can be monetary or sharing our social networks, only with your help this could be real

These actions are intended to be an alternative space for environmental education and work for users of the following social projects developed by SOS: SOS Hostel, NAIS and PSC (Social Service Educational Measure of Service).

Every month, the SOS ECO Project sends 5,000 seedlings of native species to the Municipal Environment Secretariat. These seedlings are sent to the prisons of Sorocaba, where a tree production project is also being developed.

story:
Short Summary

I am writing this book to help families who have just entered into this nightmare. I have seen the way our family courts and child protective services have eroded over the 25 years I have been involved with them. This will be the first of several books that I will self publish to help families like yours around the world. I will include other stories that families have had to go through. This book will be my current fight to save my grandchildren and will include numerous documents to prove that this is about money not what is in the best interest of the child. How our family courts are meant to be fair and balanced but are not. How judges allow lies and falsified records into the courts and how they ignore the truth because you child is for sale for bonus money. I will explain the 1997 Adoption and Safe Families Act and how it has put a price tag on your child's head. My book will have stories of how when the children are removed they almost never want to place them with families and how they prefer strangers for placement. This is real. Awareness is very important because there will never be a shortage of children and families lives to destroy.

story:
EQUAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR ALL FAMILIES

Since 2012 the International Family Equality Day (IFED) takes place every year the first Sunday in May to celebrate LGBTIQ* families all over the world. It is an awareness day that celebrates the beauty and richness of family diversity and furthers equality for everyone. Too often children with LGBTIQ* parents cannot enjoy the same rights as children in traditional families. That is why IFED increases our visibility and empowers our communities around the world.

The IFED annual report highlights the activities that were held in the different countries to celebrate this day. Your donation will contribute to the printing of the report, an important tool for our advocacy activities. 

FAMILIES: UNITED WE STAND

IFED was a source of strength and motivation to stand up for equal rights for all families. We stand united within our families, sharing love, care and commitment to create an environment where every member can feel safe and flourish. We stand united with all types of families, because every family deserves equal recognition, support and respect. We stand united with our communities, to celebrate and enjoy together the beauty and richness of family diversity. We stand united with our allies: cities, organizations, institutions, and all those working with us for a more open and diverse society. We stand united across the countries, to share the joy of our celebrations and to support those who can’t yet safely be out to celebrate.

HOW TO STRENGTHEN LGBTQ* FAMILIES

The International Family Equality Day Report 2019 will be used as a practical tool to address lobbying strategies and as a means to strengthen the visibility of rainbow families around the world. It can be used to forge alliances with other family organisations as well as with policymakers and the authorities towards the goal of recognition for all families. The collective solidarity should be strengthened in collaboration with different family forms because together, we are strong.

INTERNATIONAL FAMILY EQUALITY DAY REPORT 2019

We look forward to sharing the International Family Equality Day Report 2019. It will allow us to forge alliances with representatives from public services, institutions and politics in our struggle for recognition of all families. IFED 2019 was celebrated in 117 towns and 50 countries worldwide. —> https://internationalfamilyequalityday.org/ifed...
